i’m a similar parent to you i have step kids year old twins and one of my own and the step kids have absolutely no rules at their dad’s house they will sit up all night playing playstation and then have to go to school the next morning it would be possible to have more time here if they weren’t on their games non stop over there they have no structure there no chores no discipline no involvement from that parent at all he doesn’t go to doctor appointments conferences concerts sporting events nothing they eat only fast food and mountain dew they drink coffee all day and night loaded with sugar because they’re and nobody tells them they can’t so that’s what we get to work with my kids don’t play minecraft or roblox and we’ve told them early on there are absolutely positively no purchases on their devices as in if you can’t play it without paying for it we can find other games to play minecraft is just ridiculous… it’s a pointless game and if my kids want to gather dirt and rocks and stones they can go outside and do it we live in the country with acres of land most of which is yard and woods bordered by a river with fishing opportunities as well we have everything baseball stuff football stuff trampoline swings soccer nets and balls basketball hoop and balls a german shepherd who loves playing fetch sand box garden hammocks you name it… i even told them they could have minecraft back if they find four leaf clovers to get them to go outside and do something that was years ago they still haven’t attempted to find a single one we had to turn youtube off on the firewall level because they will sit and watch preston plays or ryan’s world and much like you i’d rather they watch better content they’ve lost privileges to use the browser because they were looking at porn it’s also worth noting that they have their tablets from pm mon friday and can choose a hour window each day of the weekend to play to noon or noon to they also have to have their chores done before they can get their electronics turned on outside that all their electronics are blocked from accessing the web rendering them essentially useless raising kids is hard this is all of our first go at it for the most part i parent my children the best way i see fit i don’t give a shit what other parents do you worry about the inside of your walls and i will worry about mine i know my kids have friends who have free use of their tablets and other electronics and when they come over to hang out it’s a massive fight getting those kids to go outside and play it’s always too hot or too cold or too windy or too buggy or it stinks or whatever i don’t care go explore the world you live in i look at that and realize i am doing an alright job with way i’ve got

just wanted to add some support to you studies show the damage too much screen time does to kids brains it doesn’t just delay brain growth it reduces grey matter…it’s awesome you at least tried to give the kids screen free experiences together in the next invite i’d just clearly state it’s a screen free sleepover other than maybe a movie or two before bed

stick to your guns we need more parents like you my advice would be to plan a few activities have a basket at the door that every kid dumps their devices in and give them a few options of things to do like you said crafts board games even a movie would be better than every child staring at their own screen

that’s why steve jobs didn’t allow his kids to use ipad his gens spent time hacking computers in their free time and he knew he had built the most addictive tech for kids ever my daughters peers yr old are glued to the screen even before they can feel bored i had to be the one to see her being left out just because i she couldn’t hang out with her friends without staring at their screen i’m teaching her self control but sometime it’s hard when the whole room you are the only one who’s not a zombie and i totally blame the parents for taking the easy way out for their own sanity even when it’s unnecessary screens are so naturally addictive to kids my m old baby is already reaching for the phone what amaze me is adults with no self control who are offering their kids screen every chance they get instead of doing actual parenting

games have had both enough time and player sample sizes to hyper optimise towards being as addictive as possible capitalism is designed to self optimise towards profitability and this is the most profitable model for games with that in mind my strategy is to expose these patterns to my kids to help them see and understand why how the design of a game or tiktok or processed foods for that matter is targeting certain elements of the human condition things like intermittent rewards instant gratification social reinforcement bias reinforcement etc i also want them to recognise and understand how indulging in those things makes them feel relative to other healthy options it is my view that they need to have the contrast of healthy and unhealthy choices defined by how it makes them feel and behave when they’re not engaging in that specific activity to give them a fighting chance at making the right choice later in life when hopefully i’m not around to moderate them my kids are still young if they fail to self moderate which as expected they did immediately and still do from time to time access is restricted we reflect together and talk about how they felt and what we should try next time and then slowly reintroduce so far they’re showing signs of making healthier choices and while i know they will binge from time to time i know i still do it gives me hope that they will feel the impacts of the binge and revert to more healthy default in a reasonable time

ask her what she’d like to plan perhaps a movie night with snacks pizza night and board card games if the night is themed this way then the kids know what is going to happen and the expectation is set if she’s into makeup then maybe a makeover night indoor camping set up a tent and all baking night where they make their own cookies from scratch a dinner night where they cook the meal maybe a pizza diy or something art night with painting clay drawing tie dye etc but yeah it’s unfortunate but the kids these days are very into technology and depending where you’re located the colder weather moving in isn’t going to help anything

you do you next time gently tell the parents to leave those tablets home they are still tweens and need to be listening to parents be aggressive if necessary will show you how many people were friends those parents just want to make their lives easy by bringing tablets i am one of those parents who don't allow children screen time at outings or playdates only at the end when i know they are beginning to get tired a friend's daughter would do something similar and i straight up told her screen time isn't allowed in my house girl ended up leaving her screen and made an effort to play with my daughter play date at your house should have rules everyone should abide by and it's nice of you and your daughter to plan activities but don't make that effort they can hang out and talk and be creative on their own
i would have set expectations with the parents and the kids hey guys would you like to come over to do xyz we are not going to be having ipads or electronics today if you guys want to come over

have you tried to talk to the parents of the other children at the end of the day it’s important for parents to be respectful of one another’s parenting choices perhaps more parents will be understanding and helpful for example not sending their children to your house with their ipads it’s also a totally reasonable request and really healthy you’re looking for alternatives to the soul sucking technology habits we’ve developed especially at a young age just because others do it absolutely doesn’t mean you have to you’re not wrong or a horrible parent perhaps one way you could ‘compromise’ only if you felt like it would be to allow your child to play it at their friends houses if they’re allowed also children can smell when parents are potentially swayable if they badger enough so being stern but gentle in how you say that’s not allowed in your house will eventually set in and they’ll stop trying lastly try to have a conversation with your daughter about the dangers of the internet things to be cautious about and that you want her to know that if anything makes her feel strange while she’s on the internet or playing this game with her friends you will not be mad and make sure you don’t get mad at her if you say that but want to be able to talk about it also if there’s anything her friends do that she’s unsure about whether she should be just tell her to ask and you promise her that you will make decisions that feel good for you as a parent keeping her safe and healthy and fair on her you might need to repeat these conversations multiple times as the brain keeps developing good luck

i'm sorry that some people are so cruel i personally agree with this philosophy for a few reasons but honestly the main reason to me is that it's just a time suck a time suck and a money suck there is literally no point to the game other than leveling up and spending real life money on in game currency for whatever little things on the in game economy my kids are and months and i already have a game app ban list and anyone saying that this will destroy kids' social lives is ridiculous enriching social interaction cannot happen with everyone's faces in their own screens all the time same games or not i think the best solution to the issue of all the kids showing up with their own devices is to either talk to the other parents beforehand and come to an agreement amongst the adults about a mutually enforced screentime limit or plan or put a device bin near the door for all non essential devices to be deposited until it's time for screen time

i just grab my kid and head off into some wilderness walk until exhausted have a picnic stare at birds and other animals climb on things swim in dubious water or maybe don’t 😦 as long as something interesting is going on they’ll be engaged mine has been hiking since the beginning first in a carrier then toddling around the problem is being home bored and seeing the parents on the phone then the kids will want to as well it’s absolutely exhausting but we have to lead by example they’ll do what they see us doing so do all the things you want to instill in them nature crafts various activities to improve the home together and so on

glad to hear it’s a bonding experience for you as well like everything with kids i’ve definitely had to set ground rules about it there was a time or two he was playing too much and getting an attitude as well i would give him a warning about this but also give him the opportunity to fix the issue himself if he didn’t he would lose those privileges for a few days it took a couple times but i feel like that taught him about self control and personal responsibility at the end of the day kids are going to be kids it’s literally their job to make mistakes and our job to help them not only navigate those mistakes but also build trust and support i feel like too many parents don’t allow mistakes i’m not sure if it’s bc they feel like they failed or something but everything can be a learning experience no matter how bad those little shits drive us up a wall

i would be careful casting insults at others we all make choices and i firmly think we are all doing the best we can most of them time your family is making choices that are very different from the majority of families that is going to put your child in awkward social situations i’m not saying that to say that you need to change but that you need to be aware of what the results of those choices will be socially i’m a pretty good mom both of my kids are grown now and they came out pretty ok one was even the valedictorian of his class they both went to college and everything it might shock you to know that i was *actually parenting* the whole time my kids had very little screen restrictions we actually had zero restrictions on the hours of the week they were allowed to watch tv your way isn’t the only way that’s ok

i’d casually toss out that if she struggled to control herself eliminating it altogether won’t fix that problem giving her limited access where to you are present and can help her with the tools she needs in real time to control her emotions will be more beneficial and that’s not me advocating for youtube if you want a kid to learn how to ride a bike they have to ride a bike to learn how if you want your kids to be smart consumers of the internet they need to be on it to learn how just like you would run beside them holding the bike seat while they learned to balance you’ve got to apply the same theory to everything else create clear and consistent expectations that are age based and relevant communicate those expectations constantly then correct behaviors that are not aligned with expectations treat it like potty training or anything else

this that’s why i give parents a heads up of what we’re gonna do if the kid wants to skip that visit totally ok but the hope is that those who show up do the planned thing & are excited about it i do not endorse everyone being on personal electronics when we’re trying to have a play date hang out for the older kiddos my son had friends over one night and one kid kept his earbuds in and was half a ed paying attention to the game i was like hey “kiddo’s friend” i’ll let you pick the streaming station if you take your earbuds out and a part of this game night he was begrudging for a few seconds then he got into and played dj for everyone we were mindful of what that kid added or took away from these game nights for the best possible fun evenings it worked out ❤️

my daughter has an iphone at age rd grade my mom gave her her old phone because she did need a phone she’s at her dance studio for hours some days and needs to be able to call me she also takes the bus home from school some days while i’m at work i actually enjoy her having a cell phone she can easily text me when i can’t answer the phone at work it’s super restricted so she can’t download apps unless given permission she can’t add new numbers and i love being able to track her when she’s coming home from school or dance

i just got my year old a smart phone most of his class has them too we recently had a situation where he was walking the dog and went much further than we assumed he would he was having fun and was gone for hours i was in full blown panic mode he’s a responsible kid and had no idea that i wouldn’t be okay with how far he went but it was hours of pure torture for me we called the police the neighbors were all driving around looking for him i walked for miles screaming his name he came back home and i just cried and cried then i turned to my husband and said “we’re getting him a phone now ” we have parental controls on the phone and firewalls in the house from pm to pm the next day he cannot use any app except for text and calls and he is restricted to only hour of youtube a day so far it has been a positive experience and he still rides his bike plays with the neighbor kids last night he played trains with his younger brothers even though he had full access to his phone we’ve had many conversations about the dangers of having a phone access to the internet addiction to pornography and addiction to using the phone so far it’s going well and i’m more comfortable with him walking home from school and stuff

as one of the kids who hated their parents for not letting them get a phone i am now entirely grateful for it i didnt get social media until i was and didnt get a phone until i was and honestly i think i was waaay better off for it i wasnt exposed to the online bullying which would have definitely happened as i was bullied relentlessly throughout school which meant that when i left school i had a break from the idiots if i had a phone the bullied would have ‘followed’ me home in a sense i am completely okay with not having had a phone for so long and will absolutely be doing the same thing with my kids when they exist

as someone who has studied cognitive psychology and has spent years doing user experience design for a living my professional assessment is that most free to play games like roblox are highly manipulative at best and straight up unethical at worst there is no age at which these types of games are appropriate even most adults don't have the training to recognize all the different ways that they're being manipulated let alone have practiced strategies for overcoming social conditioning needed to resist robert cialdini has written a lot in cognitive psychology about what he's deemed principles of persuasion which are general techniques that are used to influence people's behavior here's a brief summary of the principles [ his book influence is a good read if you want to dig in a little deeper [ applying some of them to a common pattern you'll see in these types of games * if you login every day you get a free reward * sets the stage for exploiting **reciprocity** \ because they did something nice for you your instinct is going to be to do something for them by complying with what they're asking * the reward gets better each consecutive day you play * exploits **consistency** \ if you've convinced someone to do something once they're far more likely to keep doing it * the rewards reset if you miss a day * exploits **scarcity** \ when something is taken away even if it's free people instinctively perceive the cost of the loss as greater than what the item would have cost to acquire * after you get the bonus you'll presented with a limited offer to purchase something only available to the first x players y players have already redeemed * exploits **scarcity** \ seeing that it's limited makes it appear more valuable and drives instinct to acquire something before it runs out * exploits **social proof** \ seeing that a large number of others have taken the offer makes you more likely to consider it a good idea to do as well * exploits **reciprocity** \ you're far more likely to take an offer because they've given you rewards single player games that cost real money are almost always a better choice as others have noted nintendo has a lot of great options but there are many for pc xbox and ps ps as well

wife and i bought an eero wi fi system paid for the advanced security settings as well here’s a little break down we have kid together who is and i have year old twin step kids they each have their own tablet which are just cheap amazon fire tablets the child settings are absolutely atrocious… when those are on the tablets seemed to be nothing more than simple leap pads which we were trying to get them away from so i looked into how to block certain things without restricting the tablets to the nth degree so my wife turned on the settings on the amazon account to require passcode for purchases i restricted the google play store youtube silk browser and a few other misc apps domains plus their wi fi profile is on a timer so their tablets turn on every day from but due to chores and bathing and such they’re typically getting about mins to an hour of screen time before bed we also don’t pay for anything ourselves on the games or tablets if they want more gems lives money whatever they need to provide the cash to us to buy but they have to prove to us that they have put money in their “savings jar ” before they can buy anything games need an update no problem pop on my hotspot connect their tablets update games and put them back on the house network they don’t argue they don’t complain or whine it just is what it is and it’s been that way a few years they know that the amount of screen time they get depends on their own efficiencies

the people offended that you compared roblox addiction to heroin is something video game addiction in kids is a legitimate concern here's what the mayo clinic website says about it [ consider these tips follow guidelines for screen time such as those suggested by the american academy of pediatrics model healthy use of screens and video games consider unplugging when you first get home from work at dinner and when driving model other methods of relaxation and entertainment such as taking a walk playing a game having a dance party or reading a book encourage a balance between screen time and activities that require in person social interactions such as family activities or extracurricular activities create structured screen free times such as during mealtimes in the mornings and before bedtime consider using apps that control the length of time your child can use a device keep screens out of bedrooms require that all devices be charged outside of bedrooms at night learn about the game rating categories and only allow your children to play video games suitable for their ages

so funny hang in there mama that said don’t feel guilty if you want to say something about it it’s actually not a bad thing to let your kiddos know if you need some quiet time or changes in topic from time to time teaching kids to have empathy for others is a great life skill for not only at home but for social normals with others no one would want to listen about how pink sparkly shoes are the best shoes in the world for hours right sorry it’s a weird random example but hang in there with me or maybe it’s been a long bad day and you’re just not in a mental state where you can hear one more freaking random fact about minecraft without wanting to pull your hair out despite all the love you have for your child and not wanting to crush their soul spirit willingness to share with you in the future but the really important part in teaching these lessons is that you don’t tell them teach this lesson when they are in the middle of sharing otherwise you risk hurting your child and making them feel unconfident in wanting to share with you again in the future do share with them how much you love that they are excited and happy about the topics they bring up that it’s awesome to share with people you love and you know care about you do listen when they share even when it’s not a topic you really care about it’s important to them and it’s the same way you would want to be treated when talking to a friend right do give them time to talk and after actively listening and asking engaging questions go ahead and change subjects to let your child know it’s time for something new to talk about if they don’t get it you can always say “it was really fun to hear about your minecraft story today but i would also love to hear about ” do share and talk about things you like or are excited about with your child too it’s a great way for them to learn about being good listeners and getting an understanding of how healthy conversations work keep in mind of your audience and where they are at developmentally though when bringing up your topics you might have to talk in excited tones and include exclude different facts when talking to a five year old but for a teenager you could have a less animated and more factual discussion do tell your kids when you are having a rough time or are in need of a break and try to tell them in advance so you can avoid hurt feelings example i’ve told my kids “hey i love you guys i just want to give you the head’s up that mom here has had a bit of a rough day i would be super grateful if we could talk and share things later when i know i’m not in a grumpy mood and i can give you the my best listening ears and attention that you deserve “ bottom line it’s nice to have our children share with us but it’s also good to have boundaries and to also acknowledge needs and feelings of everyone

deleting roblox account  i'm a divorced father with a son who i've always bonded well with we've shared countless moments playing video games splashing about in the pool and engaging in all sorts of entertaining activities however things took a turn when roblox became a part of our lives   initially he asked me for worth of robux the game's in game currency considering my profession in the video game industry i didn't see any harm and agreed to his request as his requests became more frequent i decided to get him a premium subscription   as i received the receipt notifications in my email i started noticing that the amounts were significantly increasing on one occasion he claimed he had been hacked and in his distress persuaded me to give him he was upset but not in an entitled way i empathized with his anguish because of my own experiences with gaming   the situation escalated yesterday when i discovered he had spent around in total on robux our relationship became strained as i denied his request for another he reacted very aggressively saying hurtful things he even called his mother and accused me of physical abuse   we've always engaged in playful physical activities like picking him up and throwing him into the pool classic father son roughhousing but now he claimed these actions were abusive and that he had been masking his discomfort all along his accusations were deeply distressing because i genuinely thought we were sharing joyous moments when he would exclaim again dad again   this altercation with his mother i believe was his attempt to manipulate both of us and it all stemmed from the robux issue i have access to his roblox account and i've been contemplating whether i should delete it the game seems to be adversely affecting him as he even attempts to barter chores such as eating his vegetables for robux i'm left wondering should i take the drastic step of secretly deleting his account

doesn’t seem like it will stop until both of you put your foot down and say no more kids will try anything to get what they want and i believe it’s our job to show them what’s correct and what’s incorrect and stand our ground on it i would remove his access to the game simply for trying to manipulate each of you just change his password and don’t let him have it back until he stops these shenanigans

you sound well intended but everything you did here was backwards the more he became invested in it the more you rewarded him he starts asking for more and more money so your solution is a premium subscription now you're at the point that's most backward of all the game seems to be adversely affecting him as he even attempts to barter chores such as eating his vegetables for robux this should have been a requirement for every cent he got from you instead it's like you handed him the power and now he's using it when you mention secretly deleting it's obvious this thing needs to go but you also want to have a convo with him for example ask him directly curious not mad why he would claim abuse for the pool antics when it's obvious he loved it and you both know it's not true i mention this because his online life needs to be evaluated beyond roblex certain minor changes at his age are expected but he still needs strict controls in place hopefully you and his mom can reach agreement on what this is

i wouldn't delete the account i would ban roblox in my house even if that includes taking away screens he can't handle it especially with the whole calling his mother do you think he really thinks that way what does his mother think

be the parent the problem is it sounds like you have set no boundaries with your son set some boundaries and consequences for breaking those boundaries personally i don't think it's a drastic consequence to block roblox for a month or however long you decide as a consequence for spending without permission there should be no secret about it it should be a punishment consequence that is stated openly will your son be upset sure but you will explain why you did it and he'll survive i would make a condition of him getting roblox back that he can only use his allowance on roblox and continued use comes with x y z expectations like time limits no asking for roblox money and no spending money without permission eta i would probably have a separate candid discussion with your son about the seriousness of lying about physical abuse and the potential serious outcomes that may come from it like police involvement loss of time with him and loss of trust with you and also his mom by crying wolf

child having meltdowns over tablet minecraft roblox etc okay guys i desperately need advice my son is and became really interested in minecraft and roblox after he downloaded it a few months ago while at his grandmothers house i’ve learned to play both of the apps with him to understand it better & see the positives they’re fun games i admit my issue is every time he has to put the tablet away he has a meltdown every time the duration of these meltdowns vary but it’s stressful for us both tonight i thought about just getting rid of the tablet until weekends to avoid this but i think you all may have more productive advice how should i approach these meltdowns and tablet time things i’ve tried giving him hour per day which he can earn more time or lose time based on behavior and activities this is new but i’m iffy on this method setting a timer so he can see how much he has and giving frequent updates + having a transition activity which he rejects letting him just play all day no limits this did not work at all obviously he is starting school next month which i hope will help naturally but for now he is home all day while i work any advice tips things i’m clearly doing wrong can’t put every detail in this post so ask if you need clarification on anything

say you only want him to use it for minutes figure out how much battery you need to charge it up to so that it will die after that much time then when he is allowed to play you just say okay you can play until it dies feels more open ended to him but kinda isn’t

i would continue to consistently use the timer regardless of the meltdown that ensues children need structure and boundaries because they can't communicate in quite as nuanced ways as adults yet i personally feel that earning more time is something that can be implemented once your child is not throwing tantrums over the tablet

my daughter's tablet has a screen time limiter so after a certain amount of time that i select the tablet will just no longer allow access would it be possible to set your own timer and give the opportunity for him to give it up on his own but then set up a parental lock one as a backup so he doesn't even have the option to continue to play i think if he has a meltdown you just need to calmly explain you understand he's upset because playing the game is very fun but we need to take breaks and give our eyes and brains some time to rest if he continues to meltdown just be available but don't respond to the tantrum give hugs when he's starting to calm down even if he's still crying but when it's passed the height of the meltdown

one hour is too long the big problem i see with my own five year old is that he asks for video games when he's feeling too tired or uncomfortable to entertain himself playing a game and having to stop just delays satisfying the need he needs to satisfy so he melts down at the end so my rule is that before playing he has to have had a drink eaten something of substance within the last hour and gone to the toilet if there has been evidence of overstimulation or poor regulation during the day so far he can't play not as a punishment but because he'll probably have more difficultly holding himself together and then i set an alarm for twenty minutes if it's a solo game like teach your monster to read or half an hour for a game he needs help for like spiro the dragon he can finish the level life savepoint stage after the timer goes off but not start a new one after that check in with bodily needs again and maybe ease back to reality with a cuddle and a story

when my child has a fit about it being time to turn off the electronics he isn’t allowed to play with it the next day like my son had a fit tantrum last week about having to stop playing a game on the nintendo switch switch and i told him “it’s not good for your brain for a video game to be this important to you no switch tomorrow ” and then don’t cave no matter what that is the most important part every time he has the fit he loses it for a day potentially longer if a day turns out to not be long enough my son is a bit older so the “not good for your brain” has been explained more and now i can say that being addicted to video games isn’t good for his brain and feeling this upset about turning them off is a sign that he’s getting addicted so time for a game break but at he wouldn’t have known what addicted meant this has really helped in our house he understands the “why” and it definitely curbs the behavior because he doesn’t want to lose the device
for me it was easier to have fewer longer sessions do you work with him to find a good ending point open ended games can be hard to stop
if my son freaks out when i tell him it's time to get off electronics he loses them for hours the threat of not being able to play the next day almost always works
with and added rule have a meltdown when tablet time is over that means no tablet time tomorrow

reacting to the meltdown may be rewarding the behavior young children don't know how to regulate their feelings and equate any reaction or attention as just that attention whether it's positive or negative child melts down you say that you understand he is frustrated remind him of the minute and minute warnings let him know that meltdowns mean less screen time tomorrow when he's calm talk to him about what might be a good activity for him to do after screen time that way when you give the minute warning you can remind him what comes next maybe drawing what he made online or a completely unrelated activity

try to pre empt it if you know he's about to melt down but be calmed by cuddles offer the cuddle before he starts that way he learns that he can get the cuddle *without* throwing a wobbly and you get to respond to his needs without having to overanalyze too much

this is more true when the consequence doesn’t fit with the problem behavior for example not letting a kid have dessert because they were mean to a sibling earlier that day delayed when it is a natural consequence that was immediately explained is psychologically different i’m not denying that he’ll probably have another meltdown tomorrow about not getting the tablet but that doesn’t mean they should just let him have it especially with screen addiction being a concern a tweak that could be made to have it be even more of a natural consequence is to have a system where when he stops playing it he plugs it in to charge for the next day if he has a fit and mom or dad has to take it then “oh hey you had a fit instead of plugging it into the charger so now it’s dead ”

young children lack the capacity for forethought not developed until around age which is kind of required for understanding of delayed punishments saying your actions now will have an effect on you tomorrow literally means nothing to a year old because they don't understand the concept then when tomorrow comes and they don't get their tablet they're not going to make the connection of oh it was because of this thing i did yesterday its just mommy is mean and not giving me my tablet for no reason and then another meltdown i'm not saying a child should have unfettered access to something especially if there's an addiction issue but the solution is setting boundaries and sticking to them or removing the item entirely not punishments lasting multiple days i'm not going to get into the idea of punishing young children for meltdowns or tantrums because that's obviously a debate topic depending on your parenting style just saying delayed punishment for a year old is just shooting yourself in the foot

there’s a few different responses here depending on the scope of the relationship with grandma you can disable the phone line and turn the phone into basically an ipod i’m team ination but android does have significantly better parental controls regardless of the model of the phone your kid has you can effectively turn it into a toy for her and remove the ability for her to call grandma or access the internet etc take out the sim card factory reset parental controls etc this option renders mil powerless and keeps your kid happy you can return the phone to mil this will upset kiddo but also send a clear message to mil about the boundary stomping “my daughter is not allowed to spend time with people who give her gifts behind our back and encourage secrecy from us [this establishes the scope of what you can control you don’t control mil you control your daughter’s social circle] please do not give gifts to kid without checking with us first please do not encourage her to keep secrets from us [this is clearly defining the boundary for mil] if we are unable trust you to respect us with this we will be unable to trust you around our daughter we will take a [insert time block here] break from spending time with you [the last two sentences may or may not be necessary depending on how combative or explanatory you need to be with mil] then when it happens “we already discussed with you that my daughter is not allowed to spend time with people who give her gifts behind our back and encourage secrecy from us we’ll try again in [# of months] i’ll call on [date] ” block her number and enjoy the silence for great information on setting and maintaining boundaries check our nedra tawwab glover’s “set boundaries find peace” you can keep the phone and power it off and leave it in the dark recesses of your closet or dresser you can use it for outgoing calls only like the other commenter suggested—block her number and unblock only when you are ready to let daughter talk to her when mil asks you can deflect “it’s always getting lost in the kids messy room battery is always dying ” or be more direct “kid isn’t old enough to have it all the time we’ll let her have it unsupervised when she is ” this is the most neutral response albeit with an upset kid

a lot of people are jumping to rather harsh judgements based on a very small amount of information and context you have given us your feelings are your feelings i’m not going to tell you they are invalid however without knowing more about your overall relationship with your mil it’s difficult to make a judgement about what kind of response makes sense if you were to say that your mil has a history of frequently crossing boundaries and overall disrespect then that is one thing if you were to say that she does that occasionally that would be another if this is her first time then that is another so you have to look at the situation in the totality you and your wife together have the right to decide what devices your child has access to i’m not going to comment on the reasonability of that because again there are too many variables to consider that i don’t know however your preferences don’t necessarily make you mil a boundary stomping ogre like some people have suggested i’m probably closer to your mil’s age than yours i know a lot of people in this age range who just aren’t aware of all the things you mentioned in the same way you are also we come from a generation where you could call on a land line and if someone was home they would usually answer so it’s been an adjustment to the new ways cell phones create a different paradigm i usually try to pull back my focus a bit and see what the message is that the person is trying to convey even if they do so clumsily here it seems like your mil would like to have more contact with your daughter again i don’t know the totality of your circumstances so it’s up to you to take all of that into consideration but i’d be trying to see if that’s something that makes sense and if there’s a way to go about it that is more in line with your preferences for your child’s safety etc is it feasible to work out some other way to address the desire for more contact i don’t know the answer to that but it might be worth considering

i think my concern with the good bad secrets concept is that the person asking them to hide something in this case grandma but in more alarming instances a child predator is not going to sell the idea as a bad or harmful secret that will hurt someone but as a ‘good’ secret that will help them eg “we need to keep this phone secret from mummy and daddy so that grandma can call you if she needs to talk to you and we can talk to each other whenever we want to isn’t that great but don’t tell mummy and daddy it’s our secret if mummy and daddy find out they would stop us being able to talk on the phone and that would be so sad ” most kids would struggle to understand that grandma’s secret phone or uncle gary’s secret touching time are a bad harmful thing because they are being told by a trusted adult that it is a good thing and keeping this a secret is helping their trusted adult and doing the right thing it relies too much on a child’s ability to perceive and weight up the help hurt implications of concepts they don’t even understand you’re right that keeping a secret for a friend is helping them avoid embarrassment but there is a different between secret keeping and info dumping we don’t need to each recount loudly at dinner about the poos we did on the toilet today but that doesn’t mean it’s a secret we can tell a trusted adult if we need to but don’t need to shout it from the rooftops to strangers the important aspect is that our kids feel like they can tell us anything including being worried about a suicidal friend even if somebody has insisted they keep it secret the difference is that some things are *private* and we can choose who we trust to share them with some things are a *surprise* and we can’t tell until a special moment but things that are *secret* and we aren’t allowed to tell others ever are unhealthy

i think there's a big difference between telling something to everyone and sharing it with a trusted adult like going to kindergarten and telling everyone that lisa wet herself is something you should preferebly not do telling your dad is always ok

my yo screwed up big time he spent over in robux in the past couple of weeks not only was it charged to a card i rarely check on but some of it also went to a random hsa card that only could’ve been obtained by physically going into my husband’s wallet he’s been asking for a phone obviously the answer is no for a very long time but now what my yo has an ipad and plays roblox i don’t want to punish her for her brother’s crime but i don’t know how we can continue with screens in our home after this i’m at a loss and we need to address this asap **edit his ipad is several years old my yo recently got her ipad and it has the payment authorization feature this is a good point that i need to install this feature on my son’s account i welcome all tips and tricks with regards to technology i also welcome suggestions for punishments for my son’s behavior i’m not opposed to quitting screens altogether as some have suggested… not sure how realistic that is though update he is going to work to pay off the debt roblox said apple is the one who needs to refund so we are working with them still pending the hsa charges did not go through but i've included his attempts an extra in his total debt based on our state minimum wage he will have it paid off in about hours or six months if he puts in hour of work per day we made him add up every single charge by hand there were over of them he doesn't get screens until he has paid us back when he does get his ipad back it will have the new ios feature that requires parent authorization for anything and everything we are tabling the conversation about a phone until he is at least we are also going to have him volunteer at a local charity of his choice many people commented that this is my fault and perhaps to some extent it is but at the end of the day he knew what he was doing he knew it was wrong and yet he did it anyway the fact that he went into my husband's wallet really is my main concern

do some math with him take minimum wage in your state and have him calculate the hours it would take to earn what he spent then have him spend one afternoon doing nothing but chores and clock those hours that evening calculate until what date he would have to work every afternoon to make that much money if you gave him minimum wage if you feel that is sinking in then you can extend the grace to say because you're a kid and i want you to learn from mistakes not be miserable forever you're going to do just hour of extra chores daily until x date not every free moment after that date we will make a screen time use contract which will be quite strict as we work on building the skills you need to navigate the internet safely as others have said lock your kid's ability to make purchases on the device i'm not as familiar with ipad but with my kids' fire tablet i have to approve all purchases from my device so i don't have to worry also from the time my kids started playing apps we've had frequent and open conversations about the purpose of games being to make money and framed in app purchases as ways to trick you into spending money we've met some games that can't be beaten without purchases and talked about how it feels unfair and disappointing but it's all part of the game developers' plan to make money which isn't a bad thing they deserve to support their families but being aware is important don't just get rid of screens alltogether now that you know he has a problem putting off screens til he's older will just mean he has the same weaknesses but with higher stakes and no parental safety net you need to actively teach practice and monitor good online habits now so they can be his default when he's on his own

i'm genuinely sorry to hear you're dealing with this situation having a heart to heart with your son seems like a good starting point it's essential to understand his perspective but he also needs to grasp the seriousness of his actions especially when it comes to the value of money and trust taking someone's card without permission is a breach of trust and it's crucial he understands that on the tech side i'd recommend implementing payment authorization features on all devices it's a practical step that can prevent such incidents in the future and while you're at it it might be a good idea to chat with both your kids about online safety and the importance of not making purchases without your knowledge lastly i feel each child is a unique person with their own feelings perspectives and experiences and they shouldn't be lumped together while it's natural to feel upset and want to set new rules or restrictions it's vital to ensure that these decisions are fair and individualized your younger daughter shouldn't bear the weight of her brother's actions or face consequences for something she didn't do by treating them as individuals you not only maintain trust and fairness within the family but also teach them the importance of personal responsibility and accountability i truly believe that as tough as this situation is it can be a really great learning experience for your family challenges often lead to growth and i hope you all come out stronger from this you got this shit

first your son is at an age where he needs to experience the consequences preferably natural consequences that are directly related to his poor choices of his actions you need to make provisions for him to pay back what he stole obviously you need to consider his ability to do what you’re requiring of him and if he needs transportation or something else that he can’t provide for himself you will need to be willing and committed to help him with those things i understand that you’re dealing with some big emotions yourself and it might feel to you like you need to be punitive; but you will find that the best way for him to learn a lesson is for you to remain in control of your emotions state the facts clearly including what it cost and maybe give him a set time to come up with a plan for making it right whether you want to do that or just think for yourself about how you want him to make it right the important thing is that you want him to realize the weight of what he did and what he will need to do to make it right; but you don’t want to overwhelm him or break his spirit he needs to know that you believe in his ability to make better choices he needs to hear your praise along the way when he comes through now is a good time to talk to him about the importance of trust at his age he really needs to understand that trust is something that is very important to protect; and when he breaks trust with you it won’t be easy to fix broken trust takes more than a recognition that what he did was wrong more than genuine remorse it requires acceptance of the consequences that are caused by his breach of trust it requires that he demonstrate his trustworthiness and maturity in his consistent persistent willingness to demonstrate his ability to handle responsibilities and consequences without complaint when you ask him for something it’s his opportunity to show you that you can trust him and that he’s maturing as well as growing that needs to happen in small ways at first and when he follows through make sure to tell him that was what you wanted to see let him know you’re pleased with him

as someone who has studied cognitive psychology and has spent years doing user experience design for a living my professional assessment is that most free to play games like roblox are highly manipulative at best and straight up unethical at worst **there is no age at which these types of games are appropriate even most adults don't have the training to recognize all the different ways that they're being manipulated let alone have practiced strategies for overcoming social conditioning needed to resist ** robert cialdini has written a lot in cognitive psychology about what he's deemed principles of persuasion which are general techniques that are used to influence people's behavior here's a brief summary of the principles [ his book influence is a good read if you want to dig in a little deeper [ applying some of them to a common pattern you'll see in these types of games * if you login every day you get a free reward * sets the stage for exploiting reciprocity because they did something nice for you your instinct is going to be to do something for them by complying with what they're asking * the reward gets better each consecutive day you play * exploits consistency if you've convinced someone to do something once they're far more likely to keep doing it * the rewards reset if you miss a day * exploits scarcity when something is taken away even if it's free people instinctively perceive the cost of the loss as greater than what the item would have cost to acquire * after you get the bonus you'll presented with a limited offer to purchase something only available to the first x players y players have already redeemed * exploits scarcity seeing that it's limited makes it appear more valuable and drives instinct to acquire something before it runs out * exploits social proof seeing that a large number of others have taken the offer makes you more likely to consider it a good idea to do as well * exploits reciprocity you're far more likely to take an offer because they've given you rewards single player games that cost real money are almost always a better choice
parental controls are a life saver kids shouldn’t have access to electronics without them

i don’t understand why children under are allowed unsupervised internet access in the first place my siblings and i never spent a dime of our parents money like this because it wasn’t available our brain’s capability to entertain itself also remained in tact i personally think it is a disservice to your children to be putting them on ipads in the first place but i’ve heard a bunch of “pay it back” or “keep the ipads with grandma for grandma time” which seem to be easier than “quitting screens all together” if it seems that unrealistic to unscreen your children doesn’t that seem like a problem i’d like to say im not old a lot of kids my age growing up had access to family computers game boy nintendo ds tablets and even early age smart phones my parents didn’t want their children addicted to over producing serotonin so when i begged and begged and begged for a flip phone or an ipod or a tablet they didn’t budge it’s your job as a parent to think of the long term affects of their childhood edit i’d also like to add that i’m not saying all this to shame your parenting or anything i don’t have kids what i can say though is in comparison to my essentially screen free childhood my adult life is very affected by the attachment i have with my phone it’s very difficult to believe in myself trust myself entertain myself i suffer from social anxiety new depressive states new attitude sass issues i’ve always been a little snappy but it’s worse when i’m trying to cleanse my internet usage and my creative abilities have nearly vanished because of their lack of use aside from digital

what’s the minimum wage in your area for me it’s around £ hr shifts days a week = hours a week so £ a week i’d start by taking away all screens for at least a month the time it would take to pay that back on minimum wage + extra chores in that month & restrict internet access until you think he she has learned their lesson you can go into the router settings and prevent specific devices from accessing the internet even while the router is on & the rest of the family can continue to use it without any issue my cents & what id personally do with my kids if they did that

try to get a refund you need to treat the stealing and the spending differently the spending needs more of a life lesson than a punishment the stealing needs punishment though you need to make sure he understands how utterly disappointed you are that he did that and how wrong it is to steal if possible reach out to a friend or family member that has the opportunity to make him do a day's worth of work i own a business and have tons of shitty chores that would be fine for a yo that needs to learn about hard work and the value of money have him spend a saturday with someone you know who has a business a farm a large yard that needs work an elderly relative that could use someone to carry their groceries and do chores a garage that needs to be cleaned out etc and preferably let him start early then use the commenters tip who advices to calculate for him how many of those days he'd have to work to make back take him grocery shopping explain that money that is spend on one thing can't be spend on something else he spend so now you need to save not buying the phone he was gonna get is a good start the remaining amount needs to come out of the grocery budget that might mean no snacks this week no soda no brand cereal whatever would drive the point home for him explain to him what he saved and why that's necessary this might mean your yo also doesn't get her favorite groceries but this isn't a punishment it's a lesson and that lesson is useful for both of them sit him down and explain how stealing is one of the worst things you can do he betrayed your trust and that makes you upset and disappointed he needs to think of a way to make it up to his dad but he's also grounded for *whatever amount of time you'd think is appropriate* he's also not allowed any screentime when he's grounded and will only get that privilege back if he was well behaved during the time he was grounded and made an effort to apologize to his dad

> > if this is like the dog walkers i see walking like dogs at once in a maze of leashes that walker is making bank they might be the problem with dog walking as a business is the logistics if you can find dogs in the same suburb to walk all of them at the same time you can make bank for sure but remember that walk has to last an hour form pickup to drop off and you need to pick up and drop off all those dogs so the reality is that dogs going for walk is just about a full day's work when you account for all the time overhead and that assumes that you can find customers that all live close enough together that you can do the walk as group for walks means a walk dogs a day means a day now that's assuming that you actually have enough customers to do days work a week that above example is only walks a week so if we assume you're only working days a week it's a week from there you'd need to pay taxes like a small business before you'd pay yourself there's not a lot of expenses in dog walking so you don't get a ton of deductions most dog walking businesses acquire customers just through social media it's often a who you know kind of operation so there might be some facebook ads that you'd need to run and staying on top of all the customer communications will be a pain in the ass even if you have a stable group of customers there's bound to be some churn so you always need to be hustling for that next customer having said all that k a week for a job that you really only need to work days a week is decently good there's just not a lot of room to grow that business above a person operation

sometimes kids just love the nostalgia but are too afraid to ask for it themselves i remember being a kid and doing a girl guide trip to our local museum where we got to sleep over in the science area do a museum wide scavenger hunt in the dark one night years later we were sitting around at a meeting reminiscing on that night and eventually i was like “hey let’s ask if we can do it again ” so we did and they ended up making it a program wide thing where like units showed up and i was asked to write about it for the paper of course us older kids pretended it was so dumb the whole time but we all admitted later that we loved the whole thing

i definitely hovered over her more i didn't allow her to do some things at ages that i have since let her little or brother do who is years younger than her i was very naive as a child and a teenager and i didn't want her to be the same i tried to prepare her for all the horrible people in the world and in doing so i projected my own insecurities and fears onto her luckily she is so emotionally mature and exceptionally intelligent that she does not have the same fears and insecurities however i realize i shouldn't have been trying to shield her as much because i could have very well given her the same fears and insecurities that i do have when she was she moved to montana to live with her dad because she had spent her first years of life with me and she missed her dad and her sisters over there and the biggest reason was that their high school only had about students whereas our high school here has over students so i agreed to let her move and since she's moved i've learned a lot of things i kind of put her in that older sister guaranteed babysitter role that she didn't need to be in i expected her to behave about years older than she always was because she was so intelligent and she was so mature i often forgot what a typical child her age would look like or how they would act because she never acted her actual age she always acted older so when we were at the mall or something for example if she had some behavior that was not typical for her but baby typical for an year old when she was she would get in trouble because we felt that she should be acting more like a year old so she ended up kind of getting small punishments because she wasn't acting her age in our eyes because we saw her as a year old but she really was acting her age and her own eyes because she really was an year old does that make sense it's really hard to put it all into writing because a lot of it seems very very small when you just write it out and list it i don't think that really shows the seriousness and the gravity of what i did to harm our relationship she was never abused physically or emotionally but she did feel like her stepdad and i expected way too much of her so she always felt like she would never be able to live up to her expectations she craved positive attention and we gave her plenty we thought but she has told me that she never felt like we were truly proud of her because we didn't act with as much excitement after her plays or when she aced a test or something like that a lot of the struggle for most of her childhood we thought related to the fact that she was years older than her little brother so even though we were treating them the same as each other as far as how we punished them or what kinds of things they were allowed to have it was at different times for example when my daughter was five that's when she started doing chores she started with simple things like putting her own clothes away taking out the bathroom garbage and maybe wiping down the bathroom sink by the time her brother was five she was so she had more age appropriate chores and her little brother had the same chores she had when she was five well in her nine year old brain she thought it was unfair because she had more to do than her brother i tried to explain to her that when she was five she had the same amount of chores but it was difficult for her to understand because she didn't remember well she has kind of felt like her little brother got better treatment his whole life because of things like that where i did treat him exactly the same as i traded her when she was his age she feels like we often favored him things like when her brother played baseball we would all attend games and we would cheer and tell him how great he did and all that stuff after the game but she never played a sport she was always in drama and i absolutely loved it she is so insanely talented and she has a real passion for acting and directing and writing but you don't really cheer during a play you don't shout over the crowd yeah good job way to remember your lines nice job talking loud enough for everyone to hear you but we said all of those things and more when it was over we gushed at how great she played her role but to her it didn't feel the same i can kind of understand that as i was in marching and concert band growing up and my brothers played sports my parents hated instrumental music and they absolutely loved sports but i recognize the fact that my parents were every one of my band concerts they always made sure i had my instrument and the things i needed to be able to play it they always came to parades or band competitions to watch me even though it was so dull and boring for them and they always told me how great i did and how proud they were of me and i could tell it was forced but it didn't negate the fact that they really were proud of me they just didn't know how to show it because they had only ever attended sporting events i guess she always felt that we weren't as proud of her as we were of her brother playing baseball which is completely untrue but i guess we didn't show it in a way that she could see it there are some things that she has told me that i don't understand or i don't agree with her viewpoint of how we acted or reacted or treated her in general but i recognize and understand that her feelings are hers alone and they're not for me to understand they're only for me to accept and i can try to ask for clarification and i can try to get some sort of understanding as to what i did wrong or where i went wrong and i might never get that all i know is that my daughter and i are not as close as we used to be and it hurts and if i could go back and do it again i would remind myself every single day not to make the same mistakes

just say no i know how unhelpful that sounds but there really is no way around it at this age you opened pandora's box by allowing her to start the game in the first place you need very clear expectations and rules for how long and when she gets to play use timers enforce it maybe she earns the game for a positive action whatever works for you make sure you explain *why* videogames are limited brain junk food no time for school sleep no family connection etc her brain is addicted to the stimulus and it is a novelty it might take time to wean her off so you could start reducing her play time gradually if you try and cut her off cold turkey it will likely just lead to power struggles and anger she likes this and you allowed it so now arbitrarily taking it away is going to feel very unfair and confusing the ultimate goal is to achieve a predictable mutually agreed outcome in which she can have her game and once she sort of gets used to *not* having it constantly and starts finding other ways to fill her time she might not ask for it as much fyi you should monitor her activity closely in the game my kids aren't into this one personally but i have heard it is possible for creeps to interact with kids if they have public access i don't know how it works because as i said this isn't a favorite in our house but you should look into it

mine was the same with minecraft though we had a new baby and it kept him occupied during the time he enjoyed it but he began to spend all of his time doing exactly what your daughter is doing and his behavior was suffering too just epic meltdowns super moody and not himself because of meltdowns tantrums we took away the playstation and tablet for two weeks at a time first few days were brutal but he started going back to the things he used to love drawing independent play going outside etc he obviously needed more direction and help finding the next task to do to keep him occupied but i don’t regret it then when he would get his tablet and stuff back he would play for awhile and then randomly get bored and do something else much like adults when you decide your indulging too much into something and you try and fill your time with other things that one big thing starts to lose its hold over you you could start with limiting screen time maybe just completely cut out the youtube too that place is garbage and unless you are closely monitoring they’ll be exposed to all sorts of weird shit like peppa pig with blood oozing out of her mouth

if you can step down the screen time i would do that you can also go cold turkey and just limit the time outright but that will cause some distress either way i would be sure that you explain to her that she's not in trouble and not being punished often times taking away electronics is how parents punish so you don't want her thinking she's done something wrong or something to deserve something she enjoys being taken away

so for limiting screen time at my house we don’t use specific amounts of time as that’s not super intuitive but rather times of day on school days my kids are not allowed screen time in the morning or after school they need to get ready in the am and do homework or help out after school then they can play but after supper they can have screen time until an hour before bedtime then it’s time to get ready for bed and read for half hour or so this gets them about an hour mins a day for screens on weekdays depending on when we have supper weekends they have screen time before i get up in the morning then not again until after supper so probably hours on the weekend i find because it’s our routine they don’t really fight me on it as they know when there will be time for screens i do make some exceptions for my teenager as he wants to use more of his free time to play online chess and logic games i also make exceptions if someone is sick the weather is bad or we are all feeling seriously burned out but most of the time that is our routine and it works well

she's so capable of understanding basic rules sit her down and talk to her about the new rules around roblox and why you're doing this tell her set times ie when you cook dinner when you are cleaning xyz kids that age don't really understand the concept of actual time so associate screen time to events like cooking or folding laundry once you establish this stick to it it'll suck for a while because once it sinks in she won't like it but tell her she's free to do any other activity other than things associated to a screen

despite your feelings of concern being valid all your behavior is doing is teaching your daughter how to hide from you and turning her into a better liar seek some professional help for both of you to learn how to build trust between you before it’s too late children whose parents tightly restrict their privacy just learn how to keep better secrets and will develop a lifelong inability to trust others especially you

there's some educational vids from pbs on internet safety that are very kid friendly my daughter is and watches them and asks questions your daughter may be past the curiosity point about it but she might still have questions and she needs to know she can ask them safely as others have stated though your concerns are valid your responses are extreme and could have the opposite effect that you want imo your approach needs to come in a way that doesn't say lecture and punishment and instead trust and safety she may end up be more scared of you than of the dangers she's stepping into if you take the extreme approach

pulling her out of school goes way too far home schooling is hard work and you need to do it for the right reasons if you do it just to shelter her from outside influences you will do her a huge disservice you won't be able to keep her safe from the world at least not forever and you need to come to terms with that one day she'll leave your home and enter the real world if you never expose her to anything risky or dangerous until then she'll be completely screwed because she'll have no idea what's out there and can't protect herself instead of trying to control her in this way prepare her for these dangers and teach her how to keep herself safe kids don't grow an extra part of their brain which contains all the knowledge on how to handle the world and take care of themselves the night of their th birthday these are skills that need to be taught and practiced for years and years and years and sheltering her is the exact opposite of what you need to do to teach her these skills sit down with her and go over the chat with her explain what concerns you about it for example that he only told her his age after your daughter already told him she's explain that there are predators out there who mask themselves as kids in order to try and gain kids' affection so that they can sexually exploit them tell her that some people use being suicidal as emotional blackmail so that you do what they want because you're scared of hurting them so much that they end up hurting themselves tell her that even if someone is genuinely suicidal she shouldn't do things she's not comfortable with and that if a suicidal person does end up hurting themselves it's never her fault explain that some predators specifically use roblox to target kids because they know that a lot of the players are year olds etc have the entire internet safety talk with her not telling anyone her name or where she lives not posting pictures of herself or that could identify the area she lives in not giving random internet strangers her number or address etc ultimately you can't keep her safe by controlling her maybe you can do it temporarily but in the long run it'll end up doing a lot more harm than good teach her how to keep herself safe you need to focus on raising a future adult

i understand your need to protect your daughter maybe homeschool wouldn't be such a bad idea it will be a big change for the both of you she will probably lash out and miss her friends but if you feel it's for her own protection then i support your decision to take that step and homeschool her maybe educate her on the kinds of people that prey upon children children being kidnapped child pornography talk to her about the risks and why you are frightened maybe find a film or documentary and sit down and watch it together she will adjust eventually even if you are incorrect and it is another year old your daughter being exposed to suicidal ideation at that age isn't healthy

eh alright i’ll bite the legal minimum age to sign up for accounts on most social media platforms even ones that are going to be “monitored” by parents or are “family” accounts is thirteen whilst there may not be any major crack downs happening to address the large amount of underaged and unmonitored users that doesn’t mean letting your kid have one is harmless or necessary plain old texting on whatever built in messaging app that comes with every phone is still something people do every day without requiring any fancy stickers or reactions from another app to keep it fun at the same time however there’s gonna be a day where your kid is going to need a phone and her impulse control issues will no longer be an excuse to not give her one though that doesn’t necessarily mean she can just put whatever she wants on it without you knowing being unable to see what she’s doing iphones can be set as a child account that you can have a access and control over from your phone that she will not be able to easily bypass without you knowing many other types of phones have apps or similar system programming that allow the same level of monitoring with very few workarounds even the most tech savvy kid would have trouble figuring out without leaving a trail behind for you to follow ultimately it’s your choice as to when if your daughter gets a phone of her own and what she can do on it but educating her on cyber safety and what’s expected of her before giving her a phone will be more beneficial in the long run rather than just holding out until it’s absolutely necessary or she’s old enough to pay for her own and having her be glued to it

we delayed our daughter getting a phone until high school and she never complained but she was one of those kids who never cared what others thought during middle school because she was always in her own head the one thing i can say is that she did wind up being socially delayed and felt awkward once she finally cared because she didn't know what was going on or what the other kids were into she was an excellent student but it took up until her junior year in college for her to catch up with her peers socially

the research about the negative effects of social media is so abundant it seems negligent at this point to give unlimited access to technology after knowing this the # advice my high school students give me is to keep my daughter away from devices and hold off on giving her a phone for as long as possible even teenagers are self aware enough to realize how bad it is for them

my daughter is and she uses her ipad the same way you let your daughter use your phone she absolutely will not have a phone until she’s her brother got a phone when he turned and so far it has been fine notifications are turned off during school hours and after pm charging station is in the dining room your year old doesn’t need a phone

fellow parent with a year with adhd my daughter is in the th grade and does not have a phone it does not hinder her in anyway nobody makes fun of her or says anything to her about not having a phone for us it’s basically a decision about our daughter being ready when she can show responsibility and show the ability to make good choices she does not have social media and we plan to keep it that way until we feel she is ready

i think there needs to be a balance yes you don’t want her addicted to her screen but you don’t want to make it so she’s unable to connect with her friends on a relatable level so much of childhood is common experience and currently you’re denying her the ability to relate to her peers the danger with this attitude is that you’re making it this taboo thing the likelihood of her going online in secret and then not telling you if she encounters something wrong or dangerous online bullying predators porn becomes higher because she hasn’t been taught internet safety and she’s breaking the rules don’t set her up to fail or set her up to keep secrets life should be about balance i have a surprising number of friends who struggle with a good relationship with food because their parents banned certain kinds instead of teaching moderation and self control imo — she needs to learn the importance of moderation and maybe earning her screen time when she’s done her work rather than denying it to her completely

meh everything should be regulate to an extent but really name one job that doesn’t require use of technology do you know how much more valuable employers find employees that can troubleshoot said technology preserve the youth and prepare her for adulthood man parenting bites sometimes

to start i think you’re doing great i don’t know that anyone has a tried and true answer to any of this all we have are opinions that said as someone who lives in silicon valley i can assure you most parents who work in the tech industry limit their children’s exposures to social media in particular and in some cases do not even allow devices in their rooms family room computer type stuff i know this because i do not hesitate to ask every time i meet someone who works for these companies and i’m never shocked by their answer just angry because they are getting rich off something they know has an incredible downside to others children’s while protecting their own the best they can schools are beginning responsible tablet use in kindergarten now so that these kids can learn how to use them for educational purposes so between that and their limited use at home they’re getting plenty of exposure i know about five years ago there were signs in the middle schools here that said “wait until th” meaning wait until at least th grade to get them a phone or allow social media use i think maturity and responsible use has a lot to do with it and that comes with age perhaps someone else can update us on if that’s still the case regardless a lot of kids are being targeted on these platforms now by dealers trying to sell them prescriptions pills that are actually laced with fentanyl it literally just happened to audrina partridge’s year old niece this week and it’s led of an increase in shocking overdoses everywhere from young teens who are just curious and trying things that we might have found in our parents medicine cabinets once upon a time this is becoming a scary reality that a lot of people don’t talk about so regardless of what you decide please discuss this with your daughter so she knows how dangerous it is in the event any of her friends who do have social media are targeted
absolutely not don’t let your kid become a screen junkie you’ve done good so far
no right answer both yes and no can be correct in this case but if your child has adhd giving her free access to a phone is like giving an alcoholic a gift brandy you need to keep that in check
