you are not doing her a disservice my cousin's daughter has adhd is functionally autistic and has asperger's at yrs of age she would deficate in her pants because she was hooked on youtube and didn't want to stop watching what she was interested in to go to the toilet and her own mother could not smell it or would do anything about it because she didn't want to deal with the possibility of a meltdown i had repeatedly tried to talk to her about it but i was tuned out your daughter knows that you want the best for her and you are allowing her to grow up at her own pace i applaud you for being very good and loving parents

so i had a lot of restrictions when i was a kid about what media i could and couldn’t consume i grew up just as mobile phones became more popular for older teens i got my first ever nokia when i went to uni in classmates had razr or flip phones and many others didn’t have a phone what i learned from growing up with restricted access to pop culture was that yes it did affect how well i fit into some settings to this day at age people make all sorts of references to things that i don’t get but at it doesn’t really matter i feel you’re doing better for your kid than not the impact of screen time and the fragmentation of attention and inability to be bored are genuinely quite harmful when she’s older i would get her a dumb phone for safety she can get a smart phone when she has a job or saves allowance if this is something you do or when it’s needed for a job your approach of having it on tablet and not phone is a good one as an adhd adult this is one way that i manage and limit my own over use of screens
naw until late stages of puberty social media are more likely to be a disservice to her

you’re absolutely not being too strict your kid is always going to tell you they think you are when you tell them no always you’re for sure on the correct side of this argument my yo got a phone this year for communication about the bus situation… an iphone was cheaper than one of those gadgets for kids that have limited capabilities for some annoying reason this kiddo is also adhd and can’t handle having a phone it’s been confiscated more than they’ve had it in their possession for now they’re on the same bus as their older sibling but that changes next year we have it very locked down and there is no social media usage but it’s still managed to cause drama amongst them and their friends we’ve had none of this drama with my oldest personally and some will disagree with me this is very child dependent my oldest was able to handle a phone younger than my middle middle child is and still can’t handle it it’s also ok to make it that way we’ve told all the kids they can have a phone when a it’s needed and b they can handle having one we’re consistent with expectations across the board even though that means they’ll all probably end up with them at different ages

in my opinion you’re doing exactly the right thing especially if she’s got adhd those platforms do more harm than good anyway and in most cases have a minimum age older than your daughter to use i don’t think tiktok does though and it’s the worst one there are kid safe options like gabb phone or bark phone gabb phone looks like a smartphone but has no internet access bark phone does everything a normal smartphone does but it is all parent controlled and parent monitored you can see everything they do on it from your account and they can’t delete texts without permission one of those is what we will be getting my kids when they get to maybe or before that they won’t have anything there’s no need for it if i had my way they wouldn’t get a phone until they are driving but my wife will probably push for a little earlier i’m ok with that as long as it’s one of those phones

ultimately she will using the technology that you are preventing her from using **her entire life** and you should consider teaching her how to use it the worse thing that you can do to someone with adhd is shelter them i just want to put this into a different perspective for you what happens when she goes to college and you're not there to stop certain behavior or impose limitations adhd is not a disease dont treat it as such instead teach her life skills that help her navigate a society that was not made for her and it starts with responsible use of technology **poor impuse control doesnt mean she cant get better** but she needs the opportunity to practice so she can develop her skills

it depends on the child but screen time in our house has been permitted with parental supervision and restriction to age appropriate content as long as there's continued compliance to the house rules surrounding screen time barring any behavioral issues my personal rule for my son has been that as soon as he's autonomous enough to do things on his own i e walk to school by himself go to extracurriculars without my supervision hanging out with friends in the neighborhood without adults watching everybody's every move then a phone is necessary simply as a direct line of communication in case of emergency children with a parent nearby all the time do not need a phone because a parent is available to handle an emergency children without a parent or other trusted adults nearby will need something to act as a resource in case of emergency the age at which this autonomy can be achieved is so individual to every family child that it's just not useful to look at literal age suggestions for any of this i don't like the social media world we live in but that can be monitored the more i thought about removing what is really at its most basic a gps + device just because my kid might find some shitty app to use with his friends the more authoritarian i felt about it i believe it's my job to raise my son around more fulfilling people activities so that shitty apps games don't look so enticing to him when they will fly at him
children do not belong on social media you are doing the right thing there is no reason she needs a regular cellphone great job

my almost year old is not on social media she can play roblox but only on family desktop that is in the kitchen she does play video games we have had to crack down and make sure it’s only friends irl that she’s playing with no cell phone she has an apple watch with a phone number for calling she can text on there and her ipad but i control who whe contacts are some contacts that i am on the fence about like a boy she has a crush on she can use my phone to text so i can monitor most of her friends have cell phones and social media at i think you need to at least allow some access on your own device so she can start to navigate you don’t want her hiding things and accessing on the dl and you don’t want her going crazy once she gains access every kid is different so depends on the kid i have a year old too and she’s had social media since and a phone since she has always been responsible and not impulsive she’s done fine my almost year old is impulsive and makes poor choices so she’s waiting longer till we see some responsibility and better impulse control

check out mommasgonecity on instagram she has a highlight about kids and phones that scares the shit out of me my baby is only weeks but we’re waiting as long as possible also you can look at waittil th instagram you’re not being too strict you’re protecting your child from something their developing brain cannot manage

don't give in if i could take it back i would you are doing wonderfully i would only caution that you have to prepare for the fact that she is probably getting negative visuals images messages from her friends at school through their phone make sure that she trusts you and wants to tell you what she is seeing in school or else she could start to become bitter and keep secrets

read the next two sentences carefully screens especially smart phones are a dopamine punching addiction adolescent brains are being freshly hardwired for life based on their current experiences do you get why it's so devastating that everyone's letting their kids have smartphones so young their brains are literally being hardwired to be dependent on the dopamine hits coming from those smartphones no wonder depression is on the rise they can't function without the unnatural hits they git because their brains are literally forming around the expectation of having that smartphone around it's actually far worse than an older adult's addiction to their smartphone because us middle aged people made it through the brain formative years without smartphones which means that our need isn't as deeply ingrained or hardwired as the youth's addiction is this is actually some very sinister shit kids having their mental health crippled by this addiction it's nuts

no you’re doing everything right giving your child a phone because “all their friends have it” is a terrible idea and it’s the reason so many parents are awful at their jobs you’re not alienating her and you are protecting her

i do think most kids are being damaged by how much phone screen time they're being exposed to from a young age but there also is some socially important weight for getting to participate in something all of your peers are doing too could you possibly get her a phone but start her out with some reasonable limits i'm imagining a phone available after school until pm then it's turned into the parents room for overnight type of rule and work from there perhaps with a caveat that if grades fall below a certain average or too many homework assignments are missing then the phone goes away until academics are right again i do think your heart is in the right place and phones are seriously impacting children's attention span capabilities in general but in this day and age not having a phone for much longer is going to lead to much higher levels of social exclusion from her peers it probably already is tbh from a useful outlook maybe this could not only be a very much appreciated and memorable christmas present this year but also a valuable learning experience for you as parents to teach her about self control and limiting herself to a certain amount of phone time while also still prioritizing school responsibilities first and also establishing your rules for internet and phone safety it might be better to start this lesson at this age while you have more control to monitor what she's up to and she while still puts more weight into what you say

we raised two daughters right as this whole thing took off i e late s early s what we learned even then was that kids who did not have a phone got shut out of social life especially on weekends; both of ours would go to school on monday to find that their friends all got together on saturday after someone texted a group or they were just all chatting all weekend it became really pernicious and we finally gave in when they were i think and the younger one got a phone earlier imo it's as important for kids today to have access to chat as it was for teens to have a home phone in the s without it they are going to be left out that said i *don't* think it's necessary at all for them to have social media access that's another issue entirely you can limit phone use by literally taking it away from them at night or using parental controls or setting time limits filters on your network but these days *not* having a way to participate in group chats especially is going to be a social challenge well before th grade in my experience because it was a decade ago too

no your being an amazing parent my parents did not let me have a phone tablet anything until half way in to my senior year my rule for my kids will be when you have a good enough job to pay for the phone and the monthly bill for a year upfront then you can have one

yea you could be doint a disservice if you’re not prepared to give her more access to these spaces as she gets older you’ve basically cut her off form being able to communicate with her peers about what could be common interests and you aren’t giving her the opportunity to make the kind of choices that you feel you’ve raised her to make she may already feel alienated from other kids already and she’s going to have to make extra effort to find her place among them socially since she’s not going to be able to connect with them on a basis of shared interests parental controls are a available if you feel that she’s too impressionable to navigate youtube for appropriate content and other social spaces i think monitoring her use of these things instead of completely restricting them until proven necessary would be best compromise in this situation let her have a phone as well access to roblox and youtube and see if her behavior stays the same or if it’s going to cause her adhd symptoms to flare up and go from there edit don’t let her have tiktok though that dopamine pile will have her face plastered to her screen i know from personal experience because tiktok is who told me i had adhd in the first place after only one week on it the algorithm knows it’s users

i've seen students who's parents don't let them have cell phones have trouble socializing everyone else is on a group chat and making plans and that one kid is completely left out that being said you're the parents no one else knows your kid as well or can tell you what to do

it's a very hard vice to ignore and almost impossible when you're young some parents we are friends with have dedicated the weekend or just one day as *no screen day* and use that to preserve their child rens youth i wouldn't say you're doing a disservice but certainly contributing to the reasons why she might not be as up to date with pop culture as her peers

i’m definitely not found of roblox and don’t like tiktok for under year olds but youtube i mean a lot of middle schools use those videos for class work and even assign assignments using them if your kid was i’d be all behind you but she’ll be soon and you need to start allowing her limited access in order to understand how to regulate and deal with them internet safety boundaries and limitations are all things my friends and i had to learn ourselves born in our parents didn’t know enough to protect us but our older siblings did we ended i doing a lot of things we should’ve have been online and the only time we really would learn would be if someone caught us which wasn’t often
the only thing you’ve done really negative here is she’s gonna have a hell of a time making any friends
fuck it stick to your guns eventually get her an apple watch if you want she can make calls from it and text but she totally doesn’t need that right now

it's up to you but i'm surprised any of her friends use facebook messenger to chat here is whatsapp and discord honestly it depends on what your plans are for increasing her boundaries eveb with the adhd im assuming you are starting to let the reins off a bit and her hang out with her friends unsupervised at the park etc i think then a phone is vital even if just a flip handset with no net

i can’t speak for how your daughter feels about being one of the only to not have a phone with her peers she probably feels left out but i don’t think not having robolox youtube tic toc is a disservice and i wouldn’t allow her access right away or at all that’s up to you but i think she should maybe for christmas if you celebrate get a phone with restrictions that at least allow her to contact you approved contacts and restrict to time use at home example have her put the phone in the kitchen or your room to charge at pm pm can’t use it at home unless homework is done additional rule is keeps it on when she’s out at a friends so you can alway las reach her she can reach you

i’m sure she feels excluded and it’s helpful to talk about that and maybe have monitored minute daily sessions or somethn but as someone who studies neurodevelopment you’re doing the right thing esp cause she has adhd the longer kids can stay away from devices the better their emotional regulation is likely to be given that they also have adequate support its not just about screens kudos to you guys for doing this

yea i think you are doing your daughter a disservice because you are basically saying that you don’t trust her and you don’t think she’s old enough to understand the dangers you are going to be disappointed when you realise that she will be able to access the internet in many other places and you will probably have no clue about it because i bet you she’s the only one who’s parents are over protective if you have honest conversations with your children from the earliest times then you are giving them the tools to make good decisions you are nearly forcing her to break the rules just so she is part of the conversation don’t be so cruel

my yr old has a phone but it’s an iphone and her account is set up as a child’s account she needs to ask my permission to download anything and i can monitor her phone from my devices i have not allowed her access to social media yet she’s one of the last in her grade to have no social media accounts i do not regret it

as someone who grew up similarly yes you're setting her back socially i cannot say it did not impact where i am now because it absolutely did limiting use is all well and good but denying such an integral part of society completely puts kids in really messy situations being ostracized sucks being bullied is worse

you know your kid best but if you get her a phone you gotta monitor it super closely this applies to all kids to some degree but my time in spec ed has shown me that phones and adhd are a bad mix in kids good luck it’s a hard decision

my son has adhd and he has had a phone since he was in kindergarten our routine was it would go in the backpack when he got home it would go straight to a bowl if he wanted to use it for games he would ask and we would let him have it for min during the week as long as homework and chores were done i also installed google family link both my husband and i are supervisors and can lock his phone from anywhere or block apps however he didn't start to use it for friends until the last months my kids are not allowed to play roblox but they do play minecraft my husband will also play with them at times he also started playing that with friends he prefers to use kid messenger to chat with his friends too youtube we have it restricted to older kid on google family link i do check to see what he's watching sometimes to make sure he's not watching anything he shouldn't now that he likes his phone even more we switched our house to earning phone time he recently got braces so good teeth brushing earns phone time chores and homework earn phone time behavior and doing his best in school just like any kids we have not approved apps or purchases taken the phone away for not listening etc at times i've had to lock his phone so i could get his attention once he's done what i needed i unlock it and he can go back to what he was doing we also have set times for when the phone will lock for the night and unlock the next day it's always the same time every day so there aren't surprises one of our biggest rules is if they complain over this then they won't get their phone the next day i try to give them a min warning before the phone will lock for the night and that seems to help overall we can control content and usage he knows and it's not an issue since it's been like that from the beginning

there is gabb wireless which is a phone without internet you can take photos text amd talk my yo has one because we want to be able tor each her when she isn't with us but don't feel she needs internet on thr phone she has a computer and tablet and an old phone of mine to use at home only for data so she doesn't need a smart phone just food for thought

mine is almost with adhd as well he has a flipphone but that's it he has access to an old smartphone but it can only be used on wifi and it's usually just used when we play pokemon go we've talked a lot about how he's going to hit milestones at different times than his friends sometimes sooner sometimes later i've also discussed with him how impulse control is a struggle that many folks with adhd face and that dad and i will sometimes say 'no' for him if we don't think he can consistently do it himself all of that said having access to the old smartphone has been a good gauge a couple of years ago he would try to sneak it to bed or find workarounds for the parental controls he's got a lot more respect for the rules now and he understands if they're broken the phone goes away for a while all that to say you're not a terrible parent for not priming your kid's brain to be addicted to tech before she's even old enough to drive kids have lived for thousands of years without cell phones and anyone who would ostracize or bulky her for not having a phone isn't a friend she wants anyway
i wasn’t allowed a phone until th grade and it definitely affected my social life for the rest of school maybe get her a phone and have a rule where she leaves it in your room at night

oof thats a genuinely tough question will she be different than everyone else yes *but is that a bad thing * unclear i'm planning to wait until my daughter is at least to let her have a phone but seeing as how she wont be born for a few more months we'll see how my opinion changes in the coming years this technology is new and the long term consequences on children is not yet fully understood but everything i've read suggests that the longer you can wait the better but you also have to balance that with how society is shifting to become increasingly digital you can go ahead and send your kids to the park to play but they're not going to meet other kids there lack of exposure to this new reality will make it harder for them to relate to their peers so you have to weigh that cost against the cost of giving her those screen

best advice raise your kids how you see fit within great moral boundaries of course if you are trying to keep them less mainstream ask people going your route it's called support don't seek support from your greatest critics you seek criticism from them just make sure that you incorporate the examples of the negatives that you are working to avoid it will have to make sense to them

i have a yr old soon to be i gave him a phone he turn it off in school he doesn’t have social media or tiktok he also has adhd he is not included in the class chat and i think is better he use roblox to play with his friends they have parental controls they can’t upload anything without my consent also i have him the phone to be able to call me or dad now he can be at practice alone and call me when is time we don’t have land phone so is very convenient he communicates with all my family called grandma’s etc the thing is the most you don’t allowed something is worst better to teach them how to use things i will not allow him to use social media yet but definitely he feels more secure to be able to call anyone if he needs to

our boys got phones at the year before secondary school as it would be then they'd be expected to walk to and from school alone the important thing for kids this age is not removing access it's limiting access put strong parental controls on the phone i use family link which sets a time limit doesn't allow download of apps without parental acceptance and sends alerts should they try and access anything they shouldn't at nearly i still have these controls on my twins phones with their consent as they recognise they have poor impulse control otherwise and would spend hours on their phones we also have xboxes and playstations with similar controls it's up to you how you do it but we did the above with the understanding that phones were a privilege not a right and that their father and i reserve the right to check through messages etc if we're worried we haven't done that for a long time

by the time i had my first phone i was going on and when i first had internet i was with the acception of having intnenet at school i think at years old she will survive and be okay with little technology in fact im super greatful for my childhood memories because i didn't need wifi or other gadgets to bring me happiness and i think your doing a good job parenting your daughter if she really wants a phone later on she can get a job when shes years old and save up for one till then she whould be a kid

my preteen has access to an xbox and a chromebook both with parent monitoring but my ex her mother got her a smartphone without consulting me despite me being the residential parent and our daughter living here most of the time it was one of those things where instead of active parenting some people just buy things for their kids ie my ex never help my daughter with schoolwork or riding a bike etc but she'll buy random devices and stuff my wife and i were pretty upset as was my ex's husband my daughter has since developed symptoms of phone addiction and a detachment from reality loss of social skills lethargic attitude about hygiene homework chores etc all that matters is being on her phone it's been an uphill battle but she's started to realize the issues and no longer resists screen time limits yes other kids have smartphones but the chat threads my daughter has been involved in with them has led to a lot of drama ie kids learning how to be keyboard warriors instead of handling problems face to face thereby inviting a lot of miscommunication and misunderstanding ironically i think it's because of this ease and submersion within text thread drama that persuaded my daughter about the merits of screen time limits so op i do not think that you are doing your child a disservice to the contrary i believe that what you are doing is much better for their mental wellbeing in the long run working in organizational psychology i've seen lots of research around the impact of smartphones on brain development and mental health remember these devices not just the apps and social media mind you but the devices themselves are built to grab one's attention and hold it in part this is what's led to the dumb phone counterculture trend

i have a and year old who both have phones and adhd though not social media my son talks to his friends on discord i don't think you're being too strict at all and if i could do so without it being such a punishment i would unring the bell of letting them both have devices though there are aspects where it's very useful maybe as she gets old enough to be going out on her own more you can give her a cheap phone to use when she's out but set up limits on it as for the social aspect it might impact her ability to build friendships but how many friends from jr high were still your primary friends in high school i wouldnt stress it too much you know what your kid needs and adhd is a bitch to manage even without an addictive dopamine machine on your person at all times
you’re doing great don’t give in my girl has adhd too and she will not have a phone until th grade as recommended by the american academy of pediatrics be strong mama

my kiddo is a year younger with severe adhd we also limit screentime and have rules in place we allow roblox and also youtube with parental controls but absolutely no tiktok or any form of social media he also does not have a phone he used to have a phone for emergencies last year but lost the privilege after not using it for its intended purpose so it became clear to us that he does not need one right now i think you know your kid best but unless she would need the phone i don't see the use of it at this age

i'm raising a child currently who is at the moment and i have these concerns i want to find the healthy balance between making her equipped and appropriately aware and able in regards to the tech if the world she's growing up in whilst also limiting how much she is consumed by tech and apps etc i don't want her to be left behind or bullied for not being on trend which we all know is a risk for our little ones anyway but also i don't want her to think that being buried in a device is healthy and normal currently she only uses tech if she's doing it with us and we have agreed she has no need for a phone for a long long time but she is a covid baby mid so she's known video calls and screens her whole life it's not affected her development she's developmentally ahead according to drs and her nursery and she's very very imaginative i duno i guess it's a really delicate line is there even a 'right answer ' who knows because i sure as shit can't find a consistent parenting strategy trend out there

the thing is the more u restrict the more sneaky they get i wasn't allowed a phone i was when i got one and only because i was walking to and from school i wasn't allowed any social media or to give out my number i didn't listen to that i got social media all under fake names so my parents wouldn't find me i had to put my phone on the charger in the loungroom every day at pm i'd uninstall all social media apps before it went on charge cause i knew my mum would look and after they went to bed i'd get up and sneak my phone when i'd get busted i'd loose my phone for a period of time so i'd just wait till my mum left the house and go through her stuff to find it

i felt very excluded as a kid because my parents were weird about things that were really perfectly normal kid things i think that it’s extremely valid that too much time on those platforms is not beneficial for kids but have you thought about just letting her on them for short periods so that she has the vocabulary to discuss the things that the other kids talk about nonstop instead of just having to sit there quiet because she has no idea what they’re talking about i’m also editing to say that most kids won’t just sit there quiet they’ll start lying about stuff to sound like they fit in and their lies won’t sound realistic as they actually don’t know what they’re talking about and the kids will think she’s even weirder

haven’t read the other comments but have you considered getting her an apple watch my daughter just started middle school and this is what she has she is still able to be a part of the text chains and call with the other girls but doesn’t have access to the apps and addictive aspects of a cell phone she also has a tablet with facetime and messenger but we’ve had to take it away because she also has adhd and impulse control and her emotions and attitude are out of control when she has access to all the apps and things on the tablet i feel that same pressure about her being left out but honestly i think in the end we are doing them a favor kids with phones do nothing but watch tik toks and obsess over things they’re too young for and don’t actually interact or play it’s also been shown that specifically for young girls that social media causes depression the longer you put that off the better

it's a difficult one and ultimately it comes down to what works for you and what you think is right for your child anything in moderation is mine and my partner's motto we allow my son a phone but there are certain lines around when and where he can use it and if he tries to abuse these there are penalties for this it's hard i would rather he didn't even have a phone at but it's the times all his friends communicate through it and we use it to keep in touch with him when he's out and about so we don't want to cut him off entirely it isn't perfect there are degrees of drama involved but we've found that trusting him he has returned this trust and the issues we occasionally have are around usage but not truthfulness which was the biggest concern we have we trust him to use it correctly and be honest if there are issues and building this trust we have found to be really important as he gets older and doesn't just view us as ogre parents who just shout no and he has to hide things from take everyone's advice but ultimately you need to make the call that you are comfortable with

my daughter has had access to roblox and tablet and she still has social anxiety giving or not won’t change much the age she’s in it’s more so that everyone else has it why would they be anxious because at any given time at school if they make a mistake every other kid has technology and they could be filmed and go viral not a lot to worry about for us but they really are in a time where its more so they’re being watched what you can do is continue to help them with having a healthy relationship with technology the biggest drawback to technology is the fact that it’s an emotional blocker it can really mess with the ability for them to learn how to navigate their emotions get mad just forget about it with a screen want to do something else it can wait go to the tablet you won’t ever regret regulating screen time but you can easily fill yourself with regret by not limiting it

me and my fiancé have decided not give any of our future children phones until they are my partner is the youngest sibling in his family and he's the only one without kids and i have a little brother who's had a phone since he was about maybe even younger my partners nephew no nieces are all or below second oldest being and third being and i'm also a pre school after school teacher all of the young kiddos and under have problems when it comes to phones they're mostly anti social not introverts i know the difference lol and has huge meltdowns if they don't have their or their parents phones we tend to not see the year old for months at a time because he prefers to stay home and play games all the time it's affected their social lives as well as their behavior and school work and also i've seen apaling things marketed towards kids on social media example a youtube video called my life with my pregnant vampire family so no i don't believe in giving them phones at such a young age

i just want to say my mother sheltered me like this but way worse i wasn’t even allowed to have a phone until i was she kicked me out at and i got to have a phone but not get to hang out with anyone when i turned i turned absolutely wild and chaotic i was into everything and spiraled down quickly don’t do this to your kids give them the opportunity for experiences and to learn from mistakes mistakes are going to happen that’s how they learn you can’t protect them from everything and keep them from bad and scary stuff they won’t stay ignorant forever by learning from those mistakes yeah they’re gonna be rough and hurt but it’ll help them to make the better more correct decisions we have to feel pain to learn but sheltering kids is only going to make them crazy when they finally have their freedom keep that in mind

it's a complicated and difficult beast to tackle i came of age when kids > started getting phones and thus access to social media and the likes and was one of those kids who wasn't allowed a smartphone or any social media no youtube for about four years although that decision was unrelated to the no social media one in some ways it helped me a lot i don't suffer from phone addiction and can easily recognize when it starts getting to that point in other ways it completely ostracized me in ways that severely impacted my mental health for years afterwards i'm not sure how it is now but when i was in middle high school instagram and snapchat were the only ways anybody in my grade communicated nobody used the built in text in phones because it was unequal between iphone and android i did have some friends during that time but they had no way of contacting me outside of school due to that i was never invited anywhere because it was a nightmare to try and get my old ass flip phone in a group chat without technical difficulties i was left out of everything and i had no clue what in the world anybody was talking about i'd say about of conversations were revolved around something online on those platforms youtube instagram whatever it was i had no access to it and no way of understanding any of my peers while this is my experience my mother's reasoning for not allowing me on social media seems vastly different than yours i was not allowed on these sites as a way to control me and keep me from corrupting forces strict lds family you can probably get the gist it seems as if you and your partner are coming at this from a much healthier perspective which can influence how your daughter views these restrictions i came into adulthood having dealt with control issues and manipulation as the driving forces behind these decisions your child has a good chance of coming into adulthood with a different perspective probably even positive if you are transparent on why these rules were in place
yes you are my son has adhd and he will get a phone once in middle school mainly because of sports events but it's not like you can't put parental controls

no you are not doing her a disservice there is plenty of research to show that extended screen time social media etc directly impact kids’ mental health if i could do it over again we would not have given our foster kids who came to us at that age a phone there are so many people who prey on young and impressionable tweens even when you think you have safeguards in place we found that out the hard way and had to go through police investigations the whole nine yards as a teacher i see so many kids who do not have impulse controls when it comes to their screens they can’t put it away and then parents act shocked when kid is failing even after i’ve told them kid is on phone instead of paying attention a good middle ground is a phone like troomi it is what we use it’s a normal smartphone with special software you can enable features as you feel the kid is ready for them at its most restrictive all contacts need to be approved there is no group text pictures no internet any apps have to be approved etc and you can check every text you can also turn off texting during specific times we have had to do this with one of our teenagers it is a great tool because it allows them a chance to communicate with friends and slowly earn freedom while not giving them more than they can handle at the time

just letting you know as a young parent and i was once a year old with strict parents i mean i couldn’t even wear shorts lol my parents were so so unreasonable strict it wasn’t my mom really it was my dad saying he was protecting me blah blah what he did was isolate me made me afraid of everything and made me think anything other than what he approved of wasn’t accepted his fears became mine to process it was unfair but i wore shorts i borrowed my best friends and changed before the bell rang for class i wore the lip gloss after i got dropped off for school i wore the earrings i used myspace at my friends house i also snuck and bought my own prepaid cell phone a pre teen or teen is going to some how find a way just as i did to not be on tiktok when every one is … i mean just use the parent control i have a two year old son now and i won’t do to my son what my parents did to me… granted he’s a boy but still do you want your kid hiding things from you or having a open honest supportive authentic relationship with your child giving them access or not doesn’t determine if they are protected or not it’s being there when they need and understanding them in a time of need is the protection they need having a safe space to self express and to feel freedom knowing your there is the protection a child needs

my daughter is the same age as yours and she also doesn’t have her own phone she does have screen time but she uses my phone to chat or send messages to her friends all i can say is that i think you’re doing a great job i believe it is our duty to protect our kids and maintain their innocence in this day and age this is not to say that parents who give phones to their kids are bad ones of course but in our experience our kid tried to watch porn using one of our phones when she was and it’s a good thing we caught it we have a close relationship and i do talk to her about the birds and the bees but while she is still under my care i’m determined to keep her innocence i believe it’s best for her knowledge about s*x and relationships to come from us her parents rather than social media or porn when she becomes older i hope and pray she will open up to me rather than seek ‘counsel’ from google she was never ostracised at school for not having her own phone although she goes to a private school where phones are not allowed anyway however we do plan to give her an old school talk and text phone when she starts high school next year we plan to gift her a smart phone once she turns and i’m not sure if it matters but my kid has autism bottomline is…way to go momma 👏🏻

kids with disabilities including myself electronics are horrible for i am adult know and can regulate myself but still times i have to put timers on etc you should teach her that if her homework is completed she can have min on electronics if she gets a good test score she can have more time if she does *well in school* she can have facebook yes it's weird for kids who *don't have disabilities* not to have facebook kids version or fortnite i don't allow my year old to have roblox because of the human trafficking that's been going on with it also i make sure my kid does the *talking part* with me in the room and only with his *school friends* but disability you need to communicate with his teacher and see how it *goes* when you *do try* if it becomes a *problem* stop if not keep it regulated with positive behavior gets a reward

i've struggled with this too important to note my son has adhd so i do understand that the impulsive thoughts that he *has to have it * are really strong but i wanted to encourage him to save for actual things he wants as well as to eventually learn that if he can wait the impulse out it will pass my solution was to say that he can only buy virtual currency once per school term this has been working well for us so far his savings grow till he can finally buy something meaningful but he also gets to treat himself to some robux etc several times a year

i would try to gently nudge my kids in the right path but ultimately it’s their decision and i respect it perhaps remind him he is saving up for the backpack before relenting still his decision but sometimes it helps with impulsive behavior to slow them down and have them think for a moment i do this with my kids and husband do they still sometimes spend their money on crap i find worthless absolutely but sometimes it works and they had just gotten too excited for rational thinking

daughter bought robux on my card for a second time not sure if my punishment is enough i've never posted here but i'm looking for some advice ideas my year old daughter loves roblox and she used to get screentime to call her friends and play together on her ipad over a week ago i noticed i got locked out of my amazon account and when i checked my email to get back into my account there were hundreds of dollars of suspicious charges the customer service rep confirmed it was roblox and it took over an hour over the phone but luckily they refunded it all they said it can be tricky to get refunded my daughter had her ipad taken away and wasn't allowed to talk to friends for a week i was under the impression that her ipad wasn't in kid mode and that must've allowed the purchases because in four years she had never bought anything before today after a talk and promises to never ever do that again i gave her the ipad back with kid mode on sure enough though i was going through my email and i found a ton of purchases again only a couple of hours after she got it back i was furious we had another long conversation about how wrong it is to steal from mom and how disappointed and disgusted i am and i said that her ipad is gone indefinitely i'll have to call amazon in the morning again to hopefully get that money back too because i'm broke long story short i quit my job to care for my terminally ill mother and i haven't found anything remote yet so i only have a couple hundred dollars in my checking as it is i'm fucked if amazon doesn't refund me she was told there would again be no friends no tv or anything fun tomorrow especially just working with me outside or doing cleaning around the house i feel like i don't know how to make it sink in or what to say to make her understand i never would've dreamed of doing this to my parents and she looked ashamed but i feel like i don't know if she gets it hell i question if she's just so short sighted that she didn't think there'd be any consequences or if she just doesn't respect me because she ignored everything we had just talked about is there something i'm missing to make her understand i tried to explain that when she buys things online with my card it's the same thing as reaching in my wallet and pulling out money i'm just not sure if it's not a serious enough consequence or if i need to focus more on how i discuss it with her to make her realize her wrongs i worry that she's not afraid of consequences or doesn't care enough about them which tells me that maybe i'm missing the mark and not getting through to her is there something else i should add for a punishment is there more i should add to the discussion i was flustered so i didn't ask about why she did it just focused on how it felt to have her do that to me for a second time honestly i don't know if the 'why' matters i'm just hurt afraid i can't get that money back and feeling like i don't have my kid's respect tl;dr my daughter made in game purchases on my card was punished and immediately did it a second time when she got it back not sure if my punishments or discussions are enough to make her change her behavior and understand how terrible stealing is how can i help her understand how serious this is and be sure she respects me edit thank you everyone for the responses and suggestions roblox is gone for sure i will continue my discussion with money and i will have her earn the money back i will say that after the first time i changed up the passwords made sure that she couldn't get into my account without a second different password and i had assumed that without my adult account she couldn't make any purchases because the older ipad she had would always block purchases unless i logged in i've gone through the game with her before and there are a lot of ads and in game purchases but she pointed them out to me and said you have to buy those so don't click on them so naively i thought she knew to never buy anything as this was long before the problem began i will talk to her more about the 'why' again because i know she likes to video chat her friends and she might have felt pressured to buy that

a lot of good info here about cognitive behavior modification vs your daughter i completely understand the impulse but it isn't really fair to take away your daughter's ipad because she can't compete against phd designed software disconnect your daughter's ipad amazon account and roblox from your credit card call amazon tech support if you need help doing it i understand the impulse for wanting them to be screen free but nowadays these tablets are how kids communicate with their friends my son has friends across the country and in some cases in other countries that he used his tablet and roblox to talk to as much as we may dislike it these tablets are going to be a part of their lives

honesty she is young and she might not grasp the concept of bills and budgets not seeing money or a credit card or check might not make it click in her head that it’s money because it’s not a tangible thing for the well being of your child’s mental health and development i would stray away from punishing her with food as some have stated i would also not throw your financial status in her face explaining frugality is one thing saying now we can’t pay bills because of you is another being mindful of your lessons and how they could be interpreted by a young undeveloped mind will help some good framework for lesson learning can be “think of good deeds you can do to earn privileges” this can be behaving well using polite manners with everyone quietly doing an activity helping with housework helping put away groceries etc explaining why she cannot have the ipad until a time you deem appropriate age appropriate homework for summer enrichment maybe money or math oriented to allow for stimulation for understanding work on figuring out how it was able to happen and stop it from happening kid mode does not protect your passwords or saved payment methods so maybe that’s why is leading to it many apps allow apple pay amazon pay paypal etc you could absolutely sell the ipad for funds if necessary because clearly providing for your family is important also you could make it a password requirement for any game download and if it says in app purchases act accordingly i can see how frustrating and scary it is for you to have hundreds of dollars hanging in the balance remember it was likely not out of malice if you’re unsure of the logistics it’s likely your daughter doesn’t understand either good on you for looking for help and answers good luck

hey i work customer service for amazon and get calls like this all the time that i then have to transfer to a special department for them to see if it can refunded every day and a lot of times the that amazon would do the right thing and refund you i learned just how poor i was growing up at the age of after my mother died i was in a taco bell with my father and sister and had decided what i wanted to eat i told my dad i wanted two things off of their value menu at the time and he was blunt with me that i couldn't get both due to not having the money i was taken aback that the lowest of cost items were unobtainable my dad worked three jobs at that time to make ends meet because he had to quit his job on the coast to come back home and raise us full time from that point on i made it as someone who has studied cognitive psychology and has spent years doing user experience design for a living my professional assessment is that most free to play games are highly manipulative at best and straight up unethical at worst waiting until she has better self control will likely be a permanent ban even most adults don't have the training to recognize all the different ways that they're being manipulated let alone have practiced strategies for overcoming social conditioning needed to resist robert cialdini has written a lot in cognitive psychology about what he's deemed principles of persuasion which are general techniques that are used to influence people's behavior here's a brief summary of the principles [ his book influence is a good read if you want to dig in a little deeper [ applying some of them to a common pattern you'll see in these types of games * if you login every day you get a free reward * sets the stage for exploiting **reciprocity** \ because they did something nice for you your instinct is going to be to do something for them by complying with what they're asking * the reward gets better each consecutive day you play * exploits **consistency** \ if you've convinced someone to do something once they're far more likely to keep doing it * the rewards reset if you miss a day * exploits **scarcity** \ when something is taken away even if it's free people instinctively perceive the cost of the loss as greater than what the item would have cost to acquire * after you get the bonus you'll presented with a limited offer to purchase something only available to the first x players y players have already redeemed * exploits **scarcity** \ seeing that it's limited makes it appear more valuable and drives instinct to acquire something before it runs out * exploits **social proof** \ seeing that a large number of others have taken the offer makes you more likely to consider it a good idea to do as well * exploits **reciprocity** \ you're far more likely to take an offer because they've given you rewards

i think we likely have very different parenting styles i don’t think my children should ever feel shame unless they’ve done something truly awful an year old having access to an addictive game and a credit card and acting on it is not something i would want my child feeling shame over i think this is a parenting failure more than the child’s failure i wouldn’t put cookies in front of my two year olds and expect them to have the discipline to not eat them i wouldn’t give my eight year old access to an addictive video game and a credit card and expect her to have the self discipline to just not use it those are not age appropriate expectations you’re setting the child up for failure there are full on adults who are broke and still buy in app purchases we expect the eight year old to have more self control than many adults if you do have children i would encourage you to look into the impact of shame on children it impacts their self esteem their self worth and their picture of who they are as a person and often times becomes a self fulfilling prophecy e g “you are bad and should be ashamed because you bought roblox” now the child internalizes that she is bad next time she’s considering her actions she thinks i am bad what would a bad girl do there has been tons of research done on this and particularly the impact of shame actions are bad children aren’t bad again i think we likely have extremely different views including our parenting styles

something i'm finding works well for encouraging balance is the one hour rule so in my house our rule is that you can spend a maximum of one hour at a time just sitting on a device after an hour you have to get up and do something else preferably something either productive or active for at least an hour before screen time is on the table again screen time is a privilege not a right of course and if you complain about the rules or use it inappropriately it can be taken away i want my kids to take away the lesson that screens should be just one of several possible options a maximum of of their free time after you take into account sleeping time chores time meal time ect works out to a very small portion of his day maybe of his day max and some days none at all because we're busy i feel that's a very reasonable amount of time to spend on screens

i would start by not telling her about when your getting paid she doesn’t need to know it sucks but sometimes in situations like these you just have to say no and mean it it’s hard when they get mad and throw fits but you need to nip this in the bud now before she is acting this way when shes it’ll be a lot worse then you could also try having her do easy chores and give her like five bucks a week or even two weeks and she’ll have to make it last for her games or whatever then she can start learning early about money and managing it

>she complains constantly her brothers birthday in thursday she's going to cry and whine that she's not getting anything and he gets more stuff than her what you haven't said is how you respond to complaining and whining and presumably having tantrums constantly your response to this is going to be important in well mine anyway a response draw your line make your expectations clean set boundaries then stick to them never ever cave or compromise one thing and that's it then do the one thing and nothing else don't negotiate with terrorists is my favourite term when talking about dealing with children im sorry that your early life kinda sucked; and from experience i know how that parlays into overcompensation and spoiling of one's kids but you're not doing _yourself_ or her to be honest an favours by not setting reasonable expectations and enforcing limits next time before you get her anything sit her down hey its tuesday that means we go to the store when we get there i will get you _one_ <thing she wants> but that's it until next tuesday and i mean it no tantrums no complaining and then do not under any circumstances go back on that until next tuesday if you do this two or three cycles in a row and hold to your restriction and promise then im willing to bet it goes away but during those first few cycles you're in for a rough time whining complaints im sorry i said one you got one that's it until tuesday be prepared for how you handle a tantrum my advice ignore her completely if she wants to flop on the floor and throw stuff and act like err a yr old having a tantrum ignore her i mean like make sure she doesn't hurt herself but otherwise whe she gets in your face and screams in your ear calmly turn to her and say im sorry you feel that way but you're not behaving very nicely come back to me when you're willing to behave nicely and not scream in my ear gonna be tough but it will bear fruit this will sound rather cold but i think its appropriate as a parent your job isn't to be your child's best friend if your child winds up being your best friend that's a bonus and of course im not saying not to love your child to the moon and back and show it every minute of every day but your job isn't to cater and pamper their every need and whim your job is to get them to adulthood and lead by example and part of that is learning there are rules and limits and expectations and boundaries giving them everything they want when they want isn't going to teach them to be anything but needy helpless codependent whiners edit another thing as i come back to this a few hours later you're the parent don't feel the need to ever explain or justify any rule or decision to your kids just keep it simple sorry we can't afford it what are they gonna do audit the books or no i said no that's all you need to know is no or and this actually worked with my kids yep i said so completely arbitrary reason guess what im the adult i get to make up arbitrary rules im the parent deal with it when you're the adult you get to make arbitrary rules for you kids circle of life go ask grandma and grandpa they'll tell ya the same thing they made arbitrary rules that i thought sucked when i was your age so im just passing the buck onto you < i like this one because it shows you acknowledge the unfairness i e acknowledge their pain shows _empathy_ you just don't care

maybe your daughter and yourself might benefit from spending good quality time together it sounds like your daughter is trying to get something from you she's asking for material things because you probably have given her a lot of things seeing that you feel bad you've always had trouble bonding with her so that's what she knows to ask but it might be positive to shift the perspective and give more importance to time spent together etc maybe also to tell her why you appreciate and love her as a person why she is valuable and slowly start shifting the narrative you have that you can only provide things and that she needs those things my interpretation might be a stretch and of you don't recognize yourself in it please ignore my comment you don't really say enough to make such assumptions but something told me it might be part of what's going on and with many people commenting saying you need to tell her no and she must learn i think it's also important that you learn how to give differently i don't think a child that age is responsible for behaving that way and i think there's no need to blame anyone but rather to change what can be changed hopefully for the best good luck

she's at an age where you can start to teach her about financial responsibility while forming boundaries tell her she needs to work for the things she wants dole out allowance appropriate to the level of chores she can complete and let her spend her money on whatever she wants but that's it if she can't afford the item she can't purchase it if she runs out of money and wants something else she can't get it until she has earned the money and stick to it no means no it will be rough on you while she gets used to the seriousness of the situation but it will get better over time with my kid his dad has a tough time setting boundaries because he hates seeing him upset i think of it as some growing pains now for an easy pay off later this comes around when he watches our son and then wonders why he can't get him to do the same things i can it's tough but it does work

time to introduce the word no into your vocabulary this is different than your normal no it is still no in minutes minutes minutes hours and days later start now by sitting them both down and letting them know there is a new mom in town and this non stop begging whining will not be tolerated anymore i guarantee she does not do it at school she does it with you because she can if she starts she gets warned and if she continues she gets sent to her room or removed etc the key will be to explain before hand and then stick to it

the one thing you need to understand is that you are setting her up for disaster if you were at the park with her and noticed a large unleashed dog nearby my sense is that you would consider the possibility that it could be dangerous and then react calling her to you going up to her and standing by in a way to prevent any potential injury everything you're doing is nurturing a sense of entitlement that will affect her not only when it comes to money but also relationships

instead of buying everything for my son i ask him if he wants to put it on his birthday list of the time it's a yes the other he's like naw i don't want it that bad this is a tip i read on reddit when he was a baby and it has worked out really well he's now he gets the acknowledgement that i heard him and we can write it down then about a month before his birthday we go over the list to see if he still wants it side note sometimes i don't write it down and we forget it was ever said don't tell him

i totally agree with the others about not giving in to the tantrums however one 'positive parenting' technique that always helped a bit with my son was sort of acknowledging the wishes for things he wanted to do or buy and even expanding on them into silly fantasy 'yeah that would be awesome huh it'd be fun to stay at the playground and slide all night long even until tomorrow or maybe live at the the playground where would you sleep ' and taking pictures of items he liked in stores 'we aren't buying anything today but do you want me to take a picture of it that would be cool to have huh it'd be fun if we bought every single toy in the store but then we wouldn't have room to walk in our house ' but if he was deciding to be stubborn and tantrum about it then it was just go sit outside the store for a few minutes until he calmed down also your daughter doesn't need to know about your money situation it'll sound like too much money if you have a lot and it'll stress her out too much if you don't have enough and you don't need to justify your decisions to her based on finances you're the mom and you just get to decide what you want to do

no complaining allowed shut it down at the first complaint this means consistency stop whatever is happening and make it abundantly clear tantrums need to be addressed immediately and it could mean abruptly going to the car until she’s ready to stop causing a scene teaching breathing exercises to help her control her emotions is helpful expressing emotions is ok but she needs to know there is a time place and appropriate way to do so it sounds like a lot for her age but children are smart resilient and react well to firm consistent behavior by adults i’ve raised three and these tactics worked even for stubborn kids she needs to know that she doesn’t get gifts when it isn’t her birthday or celebration it’s important she understands it now the more you reiterate it without feeding into the drama she will learn consistency consistency consistency even when it’s inconvenient or you don’t feel like it if you don’t she will learn that she can wear you down good luck

you child is saying “jump” and you’re doing it i think you’re going to have to put up with some tantrums now in order to gain back your parental authority sit a the table and tell her that the money you make must take care of your families’ needs first tell her to play with what she has and to quit comparing her possessions to others get a big calendar and put a chore or two a day every day on it tell her she gets a star for each chore she does without being told when she get x number of stars then you will give her a reward it doesn’t have to be expensive if she blows up ask her to leave the area until she can be pleasant then stick to it
get therapy for yourself and parenting child therapy for your kids you need help setting boundaries and enforcing rules
yea you need to grow a back bone mama tell her no and don’t cave she doesn’t need any explanation “we are not buying anything at the store today ” let her throw a fit she needs to learn
normal year old behaviour what are your methods of discipline how often are you saying no then giving in your nos need to be firm with no back tracking you need clear cause and effect discipline

i'd start taking away the device when you're out running errands less time on the tablet less distraction to mindlessly spend plus keeping her constantly glued to a screen to keep her entertained is not a good habit when she's in school she's not going to be given a decide during boring activities she'll be expected to pay attention explain to her that you'll no longer be buying any goodies outside of holidays or special occasions if she knows going into the store that there's no possibility or a treat she'll not pester you as much make sure you stick to the plan though if you give in she'll just fuss more the next time you say no

before her brother’s birthday sit down and have a chat explain to her that she has to be a good sport it’s his birthday so she can be happy for him and ask him nicely if she can play with him or she can sit in her room whining isn’t an option i think you need to have a chat with her and her brother and explain some new rules my mom had a rule when i was growing up called “i will not complain ” essentially it was a nicer way to say “you get what you get and you don’t throw a fit ” you need to be grateful for the things you are getting because not everyone gets those opportunities if you act like a spoiled brat you lose your privileges to “extra” things like playing roblox i’m not sure what your life looks like outside of this but you might want to start making an effort to replace money with quality time family walks little hikes a trip to the zoo or aquarium a “girls day” to get hot chocolate and then drive around and look at ducks on the lake etc are all fun and free inexpensive spending more time together helps build relationships it’s super easy to just throw money at people and “buy” relationships but an unplugged walk makes you all talk a little bit and learn about each other i say this only because i suffer from depression as well but walks in nature help so much exercise releases endorphins and nature does as well
dear god set some boundaries and be firm let her complain and be upset she will learn and get over it

why not have her work small chores throughout the week with calendar and stickers for a tiny surprise on friday evenings the surprise could be as simple as a movie with chips i would go with the you are old enough to work for your stuff now surprise can be anything a treat a toy something unexpensive edit also she has an ipad i would limit the screen time if you don't already it's proven to make kids nasty also also you don't have to 'explain' to her that she doesn't need to know when your pay is it's none of her buisiness period just don't tell her you got this mama

i think you’ve gotten a ton of great advice with either sticking to no or giving an allowance something to add though i’d start being unfair it sounds mean i know i’ve done this with my kids and now as teens older children it’s served them well what i mean by this is basically if i’m out shopping without kids and see something i like for kid i buy it for just the one kid and give it to them in front of the others next time i grab something for someone else and repeat over time my mantra is “life isn’t fair and i wouldn’t be doing you any favours raising you to think it ever is what goes around always comes back around and you will get your turn soon ” this way my kids don’t expect to get something when others get something they don’t get sad at bday parties they don’t have a false sense of entitlement they’re genuinely happy for each other when they get something cool this takes time and patience and possibly tears in the beginning but it’s well worth it

i understand i have a complainer as a daughter she's and has gotten better but she still whines i have learned the power of headphones and ignore drives her nuts she knows onces i sit down on the couch and put them on she has lost all hope now this didn't happen over night this took many many days of trail and error try things out you will find what works once it clicks you will be like that worked wow sorry about your start i had it bad too abusive parents i swore i was going to be the opposite of them so far so good i don't yell no physical punishment and we do things in my house different you need to find your way keep a small notebook take notes write some stuff down we broke that cycle it's time to start fresh raise our kids with no fear of their moms we can do this i believe in you make time for just you and your daughter you and her coloring together watch her favorite movie together or her favorite tv show you and her do stuff together also before you go into any store give this a try okay we are going into the store to get a d c b we are not getting toys or junk food or this or that do not ask the answer will be no i still do this with my kids ànd they are and good luck you can do this i believe in you

my dad was big on no new stuff til x date and that worked well generally something like christmas birthday last day of school as for pay day i think you can gently explain that when you get paid your first priorities are the house food and clothes and pay day doesn't necessarily mean fun stuff for you or her

there's a book how to talk so kids will listen there are ways to say no without saying no maybe you can give her month for digital content she gets it on the first of the month meanwhile she can use a journal to write down the ones she likes if my son complained about another's birthday gifts i would suggest he start making some plans for his birthday or pick a school end present or a christmas present etc or i would remind him of something nice he's got coming his way like a playdate with a friend i tell my son beforehand not to expect a toy when we go to the store if he really likes something then i take a picture of it i have followed up so he does trust me for example he likes the model toy car displays at the pharmacy and we do sometimes have to go so i took a picture of one when with him but then bought it and gave it to him a couple weeks later when he got his report card it is a simple thing but i want him to be acknowledged and also to look forward with hope and also to be proud of the things he accomplishes i too am very annoyed when my son asks for stuff but it is normal i don't give in but i feel almost hurt when he keeps asking like he just doesn't appreciate me or our home i try to put aside the feeling and i have lots of techniques for saying no delaying gratification or setting limits

the thing that stopped my daughter asking for things was paying her money for extra chores she's supposed to make her bed and pick up her floor every day just as a contributing member of the household she earns a dollar or two for things like helping fold laundry or emptying the dishwasher when she saw something she wanted at the store i'd tell her it's you can bring your chore money back next time if you'd like to buy it then keep walking if she nags complains just say i've already answered you and don't engage in the complaining honestly it sounds like she needs no ipad until she starts being kind and appreciative make the ipad a treat or a reward instead of a given

we have a rule for stores we only buy what’s on the list period no exceptions we review the list together before going in and my kid gets a job of finding a couple things on the list then there’s no arguments in the store and if my kid asks for something i have the boundary to refer to

managing expectations communicating clearly in advance having clear and simple routines and rules and using storytelling to reinforce expected behaviours so i take my girl to charity shops thrift stores quite often a week i don't mind buying slightly random toys from there and i do mind buying new plastic crap but the rule is thing and i get final approval i make some arbitrary decisions about ugly loud or just useless tat without explaining them after about a year of this there's no argument any more in fact she actively won't let me buy her more than thing it's clear that what she enjoys is the process and we're now introducing the 'one in one out policy' she's so a year old is very capable of learning this but if the rules aren't predictable or you have tied the rule to something else like when you get paid kids struggle so set up a rule how much money can she spend on games in a week keep it fixed give it to her on the same day make a big deal of it but do not give any more same with toys for the birthday party talk to her about it remind her of her party ask who got the presents does she remember what she got wasn't it great then turn it round you know your brother will get all the presents because it's his day he's going to be so excited maybe give her a responsibility for the party finding some books that connect to this theme will really help
she'll keep complaining if it works

we actually consider just going to the toys section of a store to be a privilege let alone getting something that privilege was revoked if there was bad behavior tantrums or constant whining was considered bad behavior and the privilege had to be earned back to go to that area by handling at least trip or more not going to see the toys also his most common purchase was legos so his allowance was st set so he would have to save for weeks to get the smaller set of legos that way he was encouraged to plan ahead and save and not just spend i also specifically answered whining with a calm tone saying “i will not reward that tone you need to talk to me politely to continue this conversation” i had to repeat that alot along with rewarding good behavior and specifically calling out not whining “thank you for using your polite words i like helping you when you use nice words”

some valid points and great suggestions here just wanted to say though the fact that you're asking for help means you are a great mom you care you're probably trying to fill a void from your childhood so it's understandable and none of us know your parenting styles outside of this one issue so all of those judging really don't have a rock to stand on with the bonding thing maybe counseling will help not all kids parents need to have a super strong bond some are just vastly different personalities just love her and try and find some things in common and be a good parent bonds come and go as they age and roblox has an option to do a direct monthly withdrawal i do for my year old every month for helping feed water letting out the dogs that way he never asks outside of that monthly deposit hang in there you'll find someway to make it work

you need to read boundaries with kids cause it is extremely helpful stop telling your kids when you get paid yes she will cry when it’s her brothers birthday and she gets nothing but she’s coming to have to learn that she can’t get everything you make make it fun for her as well by making sure she’s also having some fun but even if you don’t do this she needs to understand that it’s her brothers day and not hers if she can’t clam down take her out of the party for a few minutes and let her clam down with you and alkyl explain what’s going on and that even though it’s her brothers birthday she is still loved don’t give in just because she’s crying or whining cause they want you to do something keep your boundaries

we went through this my wife was going out though divorce with her previous husband and working a lot so she spoiled her daughter out of guilt every day when we picked her up from grandmas she ask where her toy surprise was we weaned her off of it with very small things and then only occasionally and then none at all there was a lot of whining and crying and we were both scared she was permanently spoiled but eventually she got over it we talked to her about why we don’t get toys all the time about money all that you can get past this with her it’s just gonna require you to be firm and patient through her meltdowns about it try planning activities to do together to replace that space in the relationship with something more healthy and meaningful

my almost year old has been like this for about a year too i think it’s just the age they are testing their powers but also still lack the empathy self awareness etc to know that it’s not appropriate they obviously don’t have a good grasp on budgeting either 😂 we just try to stay firm but empathetic and we give him little opportunities to earn money by doing extra chores etc so can start understanding what it’s like to save up money for something he wants most of the time he ends up having fun doing chores and getting caught up in that stuff that it ends up being a good distraction it’s not useful as far as saving us work because he doesn’t do a great job but he likes to try to use the vacuum or spray and wipe things or use a duster so it keeps him occupied we still tend to spoil him a bit especially during covid and being stuck at home more but we’re working on it and he’s starting to catch on

i see i misread misunderstood your post a little i think we are on the same page here in general my son doesn't get an allowance but he also rarely comes to the shops with us either mostly due to the routines we have now with working from home and covid so i'll spontaneously buy him a hotwheel occasionally if he's with me but even if he came every week he wouldn't get one actually the hotwheel display at the grocery store was a good exercise in trust; it is on the end of the aisle and he'd want to look at them so i'd allow him to stay there and go a little further down the aisle or just around the end cap and back etc more and more as he got older he showed i could trust him to stay there which made him very proud i eventually allowed him to choose one to buy i think once i could trust him while i got milk; in line of sight but a few low displays away he definitely earned it and i still give him plenty of trust exercises this way
