daughters are months apart and best friends from crib days up guys are best pals from and when oldest boy moved in two doors west of youngest boy's home in eighth grade oldest boy took a liking to our eighth grade daughter and asked her to the junior high halloween dance they arranged for his seventh grade pal to take our seventh grade daughter hubby and i met the guys when they came to the door to pick our daughters up with their mothers out in the suv never occurred to us that these were the guys at the time the guys were shorter than our daughters lol now taller than our daughters youngest son in law jokes about it being an arranged marriage by older son in law truth is that youngest son in law probably cemented things by asking our youngest daughter to test out and over th grade to join older two in regular th grade younger two could do that because they were in the gifted and talented junior high program he then guided all four to dropping out of high school after th grade and dropping into community college via lots of dual enrollment classes that counted towards both high school graduation and university graduation and then into law school together really great guys their double wedding ceremony was on a beach in oahu hawaii with all six of us parents present guys joke about their mothers and mother in law being on their honeymoon with them lol it's less stressful and costs vastly less to do a wedding like that than the traditional wedding at home is and absolutely more fun

am i a bad father i'll try to make this brief i have a year old son from a out of wedlock birth the mother and i have not been together for years i love on the other side of the country and i'm active duty military but let's not make the military a determining factor i pay child support and have visitation i get my son every spring break week every summer days every thanksgiving days and every odd christmas about weeks he has his own phone and calls me whenever he wants we don't talk everyday but at a minimum i try to make sure i call times a week we only video call so we can always see each other when we do talk on the phone it can range from mins quick good morning good night before bed to hours watching a show together or me watching him play roblox or us playing a game together we occasionally play phone tag due to my work schedule and his school schedule and most times i get off when he's about to go to bed and i sometimes miss my call window so i try to stick to calling on the weekends and days he's out of school the mother thinks i need to do more as a father like visit on unscheduled days like presidents day weekend for example the way i see it with the allowed pto leave time flight drive time cost for commute and lodging to do all of that just for a weekend doesn't exactly seem logical to me when instead i can save all the leave time and funds for my designated time i love my son very very much and i feel that i'm doing what i can when he's with me we do everything under the sun and he enjoys his time and so do i my son loves me and takes every chance to be around or something with me we play video games together we ride bikes together and talk about deep sea creatures and anime together which is something i know he loves b c he doesn't get that type of interaction at his house it's explained to me that i'm doing the bare minimum what more can i do at my distance am i a bad father

it sounds like mom is saying you are welcome to be more involved my husband had more down days in the military than i did when working full time and would go see family on those if you and him have a weekend that converges why not fly him out

put your child's mother's opinion aside for a moment because it feels like her opinion has put you in defensive mode simply ask yourself what kind of father you want to be is the arrangement you have enough for you is it enough for your son recognize that minute phone calls days week might start to decrease as he becomes a busy teenager your son being raised by an overwhelmed single working mother also impacts him and the outcomes that he will have in life his mother saying she needs more from you is a reflection of the amount of parental attention and support your son is receiving if you think what you're doing is not enough decide how you want to change your life to be more involved doing nothing is also a choice in the long run it isn't your child's mother you will have to defend your actions to it will be to your son and yourself

by your count you are parenting days out of a day year and calling less than half the week fact is you are a mostly absent father my siblings and i had a dad like that and that's just not enough time for you to be embedded in a kid's life the way a present dad is my brother was angry and would just complain about the travel time to see him and having to give up home time or time with friends to see him just to basically have everyone get to know each other over again every time i always wanted the limited time i had with my dad to be perfect so i was usually disappointed it also made me never talk about anything serious or deeply personal in my life because i didn't want to waste our fun time on being vulnerable or uncomfortable so our relationship became pretty shallow as i got older we never made up that ground in adulthood because he died somewhat suddenly

hey i'm your kid in the future growing up i only saw my dad for christmas summer and thanksgiving break we didn't have video calling and i don't honestly remember talking on the phone with him every week because he was a long haul truck driver i love my dad i always have our bond is good because like yall when we were together the time spent was very present and heartfelt as an adult with my own kids i question why he didn't call more often and play an active role in my day to day life not so much why didn't he visit more often my advice text him every day even if he doesn't respond and give him a glimpse into your life send random pics to let him know you're thinking of him a quick good morning and look starbucks has their christmas cookies out i'm sending your mom so yall can get some after school or ask him for his favorite songs so you can listen to them while you do stuff

annualize it what of the year are you with him there are days in a year you can take credit for in person and credit for over the phone annualize it what of his costs do you cover annualize it what of the time are you around when he needs a parent virtual counts if you've found someone else who can also be around also counts like a brother etc my point you can be less than half in area and be more than half in another now if you're less than half in all well then you're less than half things you can do at your distance to help him with his career so that he makes better choices than you nothing's wrong with your choices and as parents we just wish better for our kids than what we had

my son's father moved to the other side of the country months ago he didn't have to he chose to i as the mom now operate basically on the same schedule as you dad has part of summer and alternating christmases and spring break he calls or texts approximately once a week my son has a phone and can call his dad anytime but he doesn't because his dad doesn't know anything about what's going on in his life because it's obvious he doesn't care you call him twice a week mostly on the weekends during what is likely his and his mom's only free time way to go dad what's the name of your kids teacher who is his best friend you pay child support is it enough do you even care have you ever asked or is it just the state guideline what does a school lunch cost or does his mom pack a lunch for him every day when was his last dentist appointment and when's his next one and are there any issues you should be watching for does he have enough properly fitting socks and underwear winter is coming does he need a coat what was hard at school for him today what was the last thing his mom had to punish him for does he need shoes do you know what size his feet are what's his favorite podcast right now is his mom experiencing any extreme life stresses where she could just really use from freaking help pretend you have to feed yourself and someone else three square meals a day every single day this and a million other things are what his mom is doing every single day all these people telling you that you are a great dad aren't parents or are just trying to be nice you aren't necessarily a bad dad you don't hit him it doesn't sound like but in no way are you a great dad find out the answers to all the questions i posed above and then stay current on them doordash your kid a meal so maybe mom doesn't have to cook for once because supporting mom even if you aren't in a relationship is part of being a good parent find out when the next parent teacher conference is and ask if you can attend via zoom spend time with him when you aren't doing everything under the sun make him bored and then deal with him you sound profoundly unaware of what parenting actually consists of
honestly the interactions are more like a fun uncle or older brother his mom is doing the heavy lifting of parenting and raising a child and you are more a playmate

i would never live across the country from my children if my job prevented me from living by them i would quit my job if my ex moved with them across the country i would follow if i couldn't afford it i would do whatever i could to save up to make it happen i don't know that you can really be a parent from across the country you can be a friend and a relative you can show support in many ways as you already are how can you actively parent though how can you possibly be there for your child in all of the ways a parent should be i say this all as a child of a single parent whose father lived a long way away he was never a father to me i saw him about the same amount as you see your son i talked to him on the phone he was a relative he was not a father

you're not a bad father at all however i would suggest maybe flying your son out to you for long weekends you can arrange with the airline to have a staff member on to the plane & off that would give mom a break your son a mini aventure and you a bit more time with him to more hands on parenting if online school is still a thing he could even stay for a week at a time just an idea

my mom lived across the country from my brother and i for years we had a similar visitation schedule to what you described we called daily i knew that every day she was out there was a day she was choosing to be away from us it was a choice she made good money but i didn’t need her money i needed a mom parents aren’t present just for trips and fun outings mom probably feels all the stress of parenting… getting them off to school the bedtime routine taking them to extracurriculars and the fun parent gets so much credit because they don’t have to do any of the discipline i don’t think one more weekend of the year will make much of a difference in your relationship with your child mom might be jealous that you get it so easy you don’t put in any of the thankless daily labor yet you get all the credit for being the “fun parent” that would probably be how i’d feel the money and “logic” is not the right approach to this situation kids see who is there i resented my mom for a lot of years and we had to work on our relationship to repair things my brother never went through that he always adored my mom and still does but he was a little younger when everything went down your relationship might be fine with your son and if you’re okay with seeing him less than months of the year that’s your business my only suggestion is that you keep tabs on your relationship if he starts making passive aggressive remarks then what you’re doing now might not be working sometimes as kids get older they start viewing the situation differently make sure that you and mom don’t speak poorly of each other in front of your son you sound like a decent dad your son will have good memories of you two playing together i would encourage you to find a way to live closer to your kid you’re not married to the military your son is your blood and you will never get these years back i hope you want to be more involved because as a parent your role extends beyond wallet and playmate you’re more like a “cool uncle” right now in your level of involvement i’m glad that you want to have a good relationship with your son but parental duties are more than that what do you want to teach him what values do you want him to adopt how can you guide him through tough situations
yes you're a bad father

honestly being a fun relative you see every now and then does not equate to being a good parent i’m sure you guys have fun together but you can have fun with anyone doesn’t make them a parent i could not even imagine spending so little time with my children it’s not who i would want to be in their life and for selfish reasons too by the time they move out you are already going to have spent more than of all the time you will ever spend with them i’m already feeling the horror of when i wont be spending every day with them and they are currently both under two living in another town would be unthinkable another state even more so everyone is different i guess but i would have some major regrets down the line the older they get the less time they will have for you and the more time you will have for them don’t feel bitter in years when they only have time to see you a few days a year and don’t have time for any long calls their time will be limited and when push comes to show they will choose to spend the limited time they do have with the parent that where there every day sorry to be hard on you but i think you need a reality check

yeah you don't prioritize your kid and he knows that so does everyone else there are worse fathers in the world but imo it would be hard for me to respect a man that doesn't have his kid at least of the time barring some kind of extenuating circumstance like deployment or a some kind of medical condition or something many people change careers move cities or countries rearrange living situations i mean really go to the ends of the earth to be present in their kids' day to day lives so it's just about how much effort you want to put into it is your kid happy

this is a tough question and i guess that as you are asking you have reflected on your situation and are wondering if perhaps you are so the following is built on that premise you still need to work and live your life your needs wants and desires are important and no kid needs a parent that that blames the child for ruining their lives is there any reason your home base can’t be in the same city as your son noting i am aware military families often move around if you seriously want to be a dad and actually participate in your kids life then yes you should be spending every moment you can with the kid the kid is probably happy now but as he matures and goes through puberty not having you there is likely to be an issue for him i had to leave my state when my kids were mid teens for a couple of years it definitely changed the dynamic of the relationship i had with them if you truely want to be a father you also need to be talking to the mother as often as you can co parenting is tough damn parenting in general is tough but the mum is living with your son and will have insights into what is going on in his life that you just won’t have if you are serious be a parent and not just an adult friend your job is to help your kid be the best person they can be sometimes that means making hard choices in my opinion the relationship you’re describing with your son would probably best be categorised as an “uncle” type relationship you’re an adult in his life that has an impact on the type of person he grows up to be i put it that way because it sounds like you get to be the “friend” and have all the fun times but you most likely aren’t in the position where you’ll be the first person he goes to when he has a problem not saying what you are currently doing is wrong or that it will screw your kid up if it’s enough for you then go with it ultimately it’s your decision but as with all decisions choices you make don’t half arse it and make sure when you look back you can say “i did the right thing”

how long is your enlistment yrs have you been in the army his entire life do you plan on staying enlisted until retirement there will be times when life makes it necessary to physically be away from our kids that alone doesn't make you a bad parent but just cause you're calling and spending vacation time sure as hell doesn't make you a good one if you aren't going to change your life or lifestyle you just have to sort of accept you're not a great dad don't think you're a hero for what you're doing be honest with yourself some people have lives or traumas or finances or whatever that make them not great people it sucks that they hurt people along the way it sucks that you have missed out on a lot of important moments and a lot of unimportant ones it sucks that he will most likely always ache for you but that's been done you weren't a great dad you can acknowledge that you're doing the best you can and you aren't a good dad and you can still be a good and worthy person but moving forward what are you going to do what are you capable of and what's feasible are you okay with acknowledging this are you ready for the hard conversations when he's old enough to ask questions how will you feel far in the future having a son who you only know about on holidays

surprised i haven’t seen the term “disneyland dad” thrown around here basically the fun superficial dad it’s good while they are young but when they get older they start to see it for what it is i do believe unfortunately your ex is right and it is bare minimum there is so much involved in raising a child you’re missing it i am sad for you but also sad for your son when he grows and has his own family he will discover how much you weren’t there your relationship will always be this way unless you choose to do more during his formative years you don’t have enough “credit in the account” to make it through the constant emotional withdrawals that come with having a teenager teenagers are rebellious stubborn angsty argumentative etc you trying to “parent” or discipline him when he gets into this stage will likely feel laughable to him like you’re choosing to parent now when you have chosen not to their whole life i say this as someone who had a mostly phone conversation and some weekends and holidays with a parent it will feel like oh now you want to show up and unfortunately i still get the ick from this parent even though we do have a decent relationship as an adult their affection and desire to be involved in my life now feels gross and unnatural to me and i am a grown woman in my mid s when things get tough he is going to turn to his mom his whole life and when you’re old that may hurt your ego and you may wish you did things differently but it will be too late it’s great you are being reflective there’s a lot of good advice here and also a lot of excuses as to why it’s fine to continue the way you are

i was a kid who lived on opposite side of country from my dad not military from ages + our visitation schedule was very similar to yours it was the s so video calls weren't an option but we had a weekly phone call sunday nights the only thoughts i have on what you can consider does he always come to you my dad has come to where i live times in years that has been a negative for me when your son comes to you how focused on time together are you or do you just go about your usual routine it sounds like you probably are hyper focused on the visit which is good but if not think hard on whether he may feel unwanted or like an inconvenience if you are just going about life while he is there ie taking pto to work on house projects and he is spending significant time by himself

i had a dad exactly like this and we have a super awkward and not close relationship now when we do talk it’s fine but i also have a son and i can’t imagine only seeing him a handful of times a year i feel like i barely know my dad he feels like any other distant family member i often wonder what my relationship with my dad would look like now if he had come around more he’s not a bad guy at all but he was the most proactive luckily i had a great stepdad who was there who became a strong father figure so i don’t consider myself a girl with daddy issues no hate to you you seem like you want to do more and are willing to but i’d jump on it now before he becomes a teenager and wants to spend his summers doing other stuff good luck

you are not a bad father my dad also military lived in virginia japan and even miles away from me after him a my mom got divorced when he lived in japan he complained that he had to pay for half of my ticket to visit him when he lived miles away i didn’t even know me and my sister saw him driving down the street and we followed him home that’s how we found out he never tried to see us or invite us over on my th bday he called my mom to tell her he was taking her back to court so he could get his child support lowered she asked if he wanted to talk to me happy bday and he said no she asked if he was coming to my graduation the next day and he said he wasn’t planning on it because he didn’t know if i was graduating i got a college scholarship so that was a bs excuse that’s what a bad father looks like

i think effort is the determining factor ask others have said ask yourself if you’re doing more than minimum are you doing the best you can right now considering all factors of your life if the answer is yes i think it’s good enough the only thing that popped into my mind was maybe start writing your son letters i know you guys talk on the phone and visit when you can when scheduled but writing a card or hand written letter is something that takes time and effort and isn’t a monetary gift like you aren’t trying to buy his love or send him gifts all the time no one wants that it’s a clear effort to show you were thinking of him at a time he wasn’t available couldn’t talk on the phone or you were on a work break and he’s at school and you took the time to write this down put a literal stamp on it and mail it across the country maybe find cool postcards to send him and no i’m not old 😂 i’m and i just think this is a cool way to show your effort without expecting reciprocation from him just a little extra thing you can do if traveling to him isn’t an option effort even small things goes a long way

not a bad father i’m now and my mom was active duty for + years her and my dad were divorced and i lived with my dad as a kid i wondered why she wasn’t around as much but as an adult i realized she was stationed miles away and when you’re military you have certain responsibilities to the government hopefully he grows up and understands this best thing you can do is keep in contact ad much as possible calls texts etc try and visit if you can on non scheduled days most military children end up eventually understanding the reality of the parents situation and that they wanted to be there but physically couldn’t

i would say the fact that you're even querying whether you should try and do more is indicative of you should be if you have capacity to do more for your child the answer is always yes as far as your circumstance allows however i wouldn't pay too much mind to what the mother is saying in this circumstance since realistically she's considering it from her perspective of being the majority custody partner and is through that having more direct involvement there are plenty of fathers who work fifo or far away who have more than enough involvement for healthy development of a child life isn't as black and white as people make it out to be in these scenarios im new to being a parent but the main thing i've learned is no matter what you do some idiot is going to tell you you're wrong for doing it if your ex and yourself aren't on amicable terms she's always going to find something wrong with what you're doing and even if you are parenting approaches and balancing it with realities of life are such polarised views that she'll more than likely have criticisms anyway do the best you can with what you have also ignore the comments about clearing things with the mum to avoid being viewed as the fun parent the time you have with him due to your working circumstance is limited and wanting them to enjoy their time with you as much as possible isn't wrong when your child grows up they're not going to be sitting there thinking about how one parent was funner than the other no one sits there dwelling like that it's all just creating memories and anything you can do to make his childhood memories more positive is never a bad thing

i’m not a service member but i am married to one i can completely understand where you’re coming from with the holidays unless you live relatively close because getting flights etc approved can be like jumping through hoops or it not even getting approved especially if you have a crappy command i also know that the military does like to make last minute changes and the pay isn’t absolutely incredible so wanting to save and be prepared for when he does visit to make it as memorable is completely understandable it’s not like you can just up and move either you’re required by orders to be at a specific location and i think alot of people forget about that and you may not be given the option to choose where that location is i think you’re being as involved as you can be i’d just say take every opportunity to call when you can maybe send him a little care package or something of his favorite snacks the two of you enjoy sharing or some of his favorite little knick knacks to show you’re thinking of him and remember those are his favorite things you can’t be faulted because you have a contracted obligation to a job that you can’t just call out of like others can while it may seem to others like you’re doing the bare minimum i feel like you’re doing the most you can at the end of the day as long as you and your son have a great relationship that’s all that matters edited to fix a sentence mistake

yes this my dad was army my brother was army i was army and i currently work for the army as a civilian it is *absolutely* a factor and there's no use pretending it's not you can up and walk away from a regular job if it's interfering with your ability to be a present parent you can just wander off the job site one day and never come back move to be closer to your son assuming you otherwise have the means to do this and get yourself a new job where you're going to be living and there are no consequences other than the regular day to day difficulties of doing those things the army *is* a completely different world in this regard and it's silly to try to treat it as though your long distance situation is the same as anyone else's so now you have to ask yourself since my army career is interfering with my ability to be a present parent to my son what am i going to do about it request a reassignment to a different post to be closer retire if you have enough time in resign your commission if you're an officer refuse to reenlist and go ahead and ets when your contract is done nothing you have options your choice is going to boil down to what your priorities are this isn't me criticizing you just helping you understand none of your choices are wrong but they will all have different consequences and you have to decide what you can live with is your army career the priority so you can ensure you get a pension+va so you can have tricare for life and always have income no matter what that's a valid choice but it may irrevocably stunt your relationship with your son and ex are those relationships more important and you decide to get out of the army to be present for your son also a valid choice but you'll be sacrificing quite a bit to do so obviously i don't know you or your life and i don't know what your choices really are these were just examples but the point is nobody ever said parenting was easy we all have to decide how to approach it and what our roles and priorities are going to be good luck sincerely

i am not military but i think this is helpful information also i’m surprised no one has said it or as far as i have seen what about asking your son what he wants keeping in mind that if he wants to move to be with you that you are willing and able to provide that opportunity for him also for what it is worth i think you are a good father just for asking the question you obviously care enough to put yourself out there for complete strangers to assess i would encourage you to communicate with mom and find out why this is coming up if she has been fine with the arrangements thus far maybe there is something else going on with her communication is the only way to have any sort of relationship whether it be parenting or coparenting i would say that it basically boils down to what you can live with even if you are not physically present there are ways to be there for your child most schools have electronic ways of communicating with parents are you able to receive the day to day school information like maybe if there are field trips or something you can arrange to help out in some way providing lunch or something if there are discipline issues you could help to navigate that be there by video for the tough questions maybe help out with homework when or if possible i would encourage you to try and have the best coparenting relationship in order to be as present as possible maybe it is something as simple as y’all ordering or making the same meal and eating together via video chat on a week night i don’t presume to know you or your life i can’t say what your priorities are but you know you know your priorities and your integrity that is what it boils down to are you the type of father that makes your son proud are you proud of the type of father you are these are just some things to think about in closing i commend you for caring enough to ask the hard questions i thank you for your sacrifice for our country i truly wish you well

please be careful and talk with your attorney first about the terms in your parenting plan i have seen judges reprimand parents for showing up during the other parent’s parenting time if mother has “uninterrupted time” specified in the parenting plan that generally means parent time exercised by one parent without interruption by the presence of the other parent i don’t know the terms of your parenting plan and this is not legal advice but i personally would not just show up without getting approval from the other parent in writing each and every time please consult with an attorney first

as someone with both parents in the military and extremely involved maternal grandparents… i would note that the time you listed is mostly the “fun time” spring break summer etc you’re not doing any of the most difficult showing up of life homework sick days cleaning cooking healthy meals lunch packing taking him to extracurricular etc you’re not a “bad father” you’re just absent for a lot of the day to day grind he might not notice it now although he might but he definitely will as he gets older he’ll want your presence at his sports games concerts etc life is the day to day not just the big moments as he becomes a teenager it will be more difficult to overcome arguments because he can simply hang up i mostly remember my parents not showing up and they definitely were there for the “big stuff”… but honestly as an adult it was the cinnamon toast when i was sick from my grandma that i miss or my grandpa teaching me to ride a bike i love my parents deeply but hands down it’s the day to day i live on the other side of the world now and don’t visit that often just for the fun times… but i know it’s the day to day that counts and it’s really sad he will only be a child for a few more years if you can be local it would probably create a stronger foundation

my husband is active military we are still together and he lives here but he does leave frequently for periods of time air force he calls and talks to our daughter every night that he can when he is gone even if it is just a hello how was your day i love you very much i miss you so much i cant wait to see you goodnight she is excited to talk to him and see him and tell him about her day are you actively pursuing a posting closer to your son as well im sure you would take it up if it was offered but are you actively pursuing a way to make it possible can you remuster without causing too much strife to a position that allows you a posting closer are there career options that while not the most ideal for you personally would allow you to see your son more often do you have transferable skills to a job outside the realm of the military that would allow you to be closer to your son why is being in the military outside of a contract time period more important than the time you can spend with your son if you are able to remove yourself from it and still maintain a healthy life there's lots of questions here that can be looked at in terms of what you are willing to do to be a better father if not i would say that you are severely limiting your capacity to be the father your son needs wants i give you credit for how much you do do in comparison but that is also like a low bar when we look at the amount of fathers parents who are entirely absent from their children's lives the minimum should be more than you are doing but sadly it isn't seen that way so you doing what you are can be seen in a positive way i don't think you are a bad father by any means because i can tell you do care but i think there is always more that can be done

if your goal is to be a father and just an overall good parent i think you should be working towards being closer to your child more often having my dad around during planned visits or going to his house for the summer or whatever it was like visiting a relative we did fun stuff he lived in florida we always went to theme parks and stuff it was an event in the most ideal situation parents are there most of the time they're available and present in the mundane times and during the exciting times they provide a kind of consistent stability of being there to guide and to reassure and to comfort and to seek care from that kind of attachment is really important and again i don't think you can really form that kind of attachment with the way your setup is currently when i was a kid i wanted my dad around i just wanted him there i missed him i wanted to share my life with him like i could with my mom my life was where i was when i went to where he was it wasn't the same nothing was mine nothing felt like mine again it was like going on a vacation what if i had a hard day and just needed someone to be with me can a video call replace that i don't know we didn't have that when i was a kid it wouldn't give me a chance to have my friends know my dad though or take me somewhere after school to be comforted like if you were there think about how many opportunities you would have for connection which are impossible the way things are as a parent sometimes the little things make the biggest difference how connected do you want to be with your child if you really want to be connected you need to be closer more often

you’re not a bad father in the least and i’m sorry that your former partner is making you feel that way as someone else mentioned she is carrying more of the day to day parental weight and could feel burned out or envious of her local friends who get a “break” every other weekend to do whatever they want on the other side of the coin i’m sure you’d absolutely love to see your awesome son every wednesday every other weekend every long weekend etc and not have to plan and pay for flights for an unaccompanied minor each time you see him the fact of the situation is that it sucks for both parents involved my husband was in your boots ha that’s a slight military nod with his son but he saw him a lot less than you see yours as there were a couple years that it was only in the summer we got full custody of him when he was i doubt your son’s mom would want to be in my step sons moms place not seeing her boy daily stay the course you’re doing well do you play roblox with him id also recommend sending mail but that can be a slippery slope so keep the gifts to a minimum even just sending a care package of snacks for him to eat while yall play video games together could be exciting for him

i think the distance is really the kicker here you sound like you're doing the best you can and as someone who grew up with my dad only minutes away but completely out of communication i'm going to say i think it's awesome you call frequently and awesome that you commit to your schedule this stuff is so important and helps your son feel loved and supported and that is super important the flip side of this equation is that mom may be feeling a lot of stress you get your son during his down vacation time mostly so the brunt of the work is still likely falling on her and she may be feeling frustrated by that things like helping with homework every day teacher conferences keeping up with after school activities getting kiddo to birthday parties and keeping up with all that that's likely mostly on her and it gets really tiring especially if she feels like she ever has to be the strict scheduler manager or bad guy in terms of schoolwork or discipline there's a very real phenomenon of the disney dad mom has to be the disciplinarian and taskmaster then dad shows up for vacation time and everyone just has fun i would suggest if you haven't already really looking over how things are working to make sure you've got some of the less fun stuff too when you call over the week are you helping him with or looking over his homework when he's visiting you over the summer are there teams he can play on or music lessons or whatever that he can do while with you so you're handling some of that stuff too are you able to meet his teachers and do virtual conferences with them etc it may be you're doing a lot of this too i don't know the full brunt from your post but it's something to keep in mind i can tell you really want to do the best you can and you are already making sure you are connected to your son and love him very much and your ex may always be biased in this regard i just wanted to bring up this dynamic so you can pay attention and make sure you're not slipping into it

i'm talking about op's intention *and* action he has intentions to be a good father that manifest into actions to the maximum extent possible given his situation a lot of 'present' parents don't have either i disagree that someone can't actively parent without being present there are certain elements of parenting that require physical presence sure but other elements don't you don't need to be physically present all the time to teach your children how to be a good person to help them through hard times and tough situations you have to be present for some things sure but not all of them and unless he's a 'disney dad' which we've no reason to believe he is then i'd imagine he's using that time he does have with his child to do those things he needs to be physically present for but most of those are superficial anyway

i avoided value judgements because i don't think they're valuable here but i think at this point i'm willing to say this is fairly subjective but rooted in the childs perspective entirely so i'm a little biased as in my experience my father never did anything to make me feel like he was a parent or any different than an aunt or uncle or grandparent and it was similar to what is being described here i think if you read my response to the ops response to ky comment you may have a better understanding of where i am coming from this isn't really about not being the primary parent or not it's about the availability to share life with your parent which becomes harder the more removed they are from your immediacy in the most ideal situation life is by default shared because you live with your parents by degrees removed from that at some point the relationship is just completely different and like i originally said more that of another relative who doesn't parent you

if it's possible i wonder if it might help to detox from screens for a while i understand that might be difficult as i'm sure you use computer and videos for your homeschooling too going scorched earth for a while might help him refocus and get perspective back screens and screen addiction are really tough for some kids and it can just be a huge struggle it might help to step back and consider the big picture of your entire school year taking a month off of screens might feel like a huge setback but if it saves your year and makes the rest of your time more productive maybe worth it in that time you take off screens you could maybe try redirecting his attention into things like educational board games or borrowing a large selection of books on different subjects and see what piques his interest and go from there and then start slowly reintroducing screens with limits once he seems like he's doing better the opposite approach could be to lean into it i don't know about roblox but minecraft does provide some avenues for creativity and spacial reasoning perhaps you could find some way to use this to your advantage you could agree to let him have more time playing minecraft if he uses that time to say recreate topography or famous landmarks then he'll have to do some research on like the arc de triomphe or whatever in order to build it in minecraft and maybe you could get him to write some notes on it while he's working on it a small research assignment perhaps idk i'm sure there's a way you could harness the obsession but i guess it all depends on whether you feel that it's healthy or not

i think it’s absolutely ok to set the boundary of having quiet time and not wanting someone to talk to you my son is a talker to the extreme i value that it has led to some awesome conversations between us but i do a few things that i think helps me maintain sanity if he’s talking about something i’m not interested in or talking just to hear himself talk i try to give him my full attention for a few minutes if i’m half listening i find he talks more and more because he’s trying to get my attention if i give it he usually gets to the point or realizes he doesn’t have anything else to say his need for attention is satisfied and he stops if he doesn’t i find a stopping point and say “thank you for telling me about that i would like to have some quiet time right now but we can talk more later ” reminders about what a conversation is sometimes kids talk us about things we aren’t interested in and it’s important to listen that said kids need to be taught that a conversation is a back and forth conversation you need to have room to give input or ask questions “that’s interesting; so what do you like about that dinosaur ” if they aren’t giving you that room it’s not a conversation in a similar thread they need to learn that while you value their interests you may not share them my son learned this the hard way when he kept asking me what my favorite sport car was and i kept responding “i don’t know any thing about sport cars and i don’t care to ever own one i respect that you are interested in them please respect that i’m not ” anyway these things have helped us have more conversations and fewer “i’m being talked at and i’m dying inside” moments

this is tough because middle schoolers care so much about what other kids think of them he probably feels scared and embarrassed because they were making fun of him especially since they're girls and he's probably hitting puberty and starting to care about what girls think of him did your son know that these were fake converse shoes or did you tell him they were real from the way you wrote it it sounds like he knew they were fake and didn't care until the girls made fun of him for it have a conversation with your son talk about his feelings and fears that he might have for example being ostracized and laughed at by the whole school comfort him and try to take away some of his fears middle school really is a social minefield and stuff like this can definitely lead to kids losing their friends or being made fun of which is what makes it so difficult if this happens to you as an adult you can kind of tell yourself oh they'll forget about it because they will but when you're and all you care about is what other kids think of you it's so much harder if you can't afford real converse you don't have to buy them i think it's better to go for generic clothes shoes than to buy fakes though because when you wear fakes you're trying to make people believe you're wearing the real thing which is what makes it so bad in these kids' eyes they will probably care less if he just wears shoes from unknown brands but of course your son probably won't like that i think you should be honest with him and tell him that even though you know it's important to him and he wants to fit in you just can't afford it this year you can also try to buy used items of clothing since you can usually get name brand clothing for a fraction of the original price that way i know it sounds a little disgusting to buy used shoes but i'm sure if you sanitize them properly it's all good start having conversations with your son about what types of things are important in life because the truth is if these girls care that much about a fucking star on an overpriced piece of cloth they are superficial and of course they're probably superficial because they're also and terrified of being ostracized for minor social transgressions but it's still true that caring about someone else's clothes is superficial your son needs to understand that there are many things about him that are much more important than his clothes or shoes and he should focus on those if he wants to find real friends that care about him as a person and are there for him try to help him strengthen his confidence does he have any extracurriculars that he's good at and or cares about that's what really helped my son who is now and was also very insecure when he was around your son's age maybe there's someone in your son's life who can teach him how to respond to mean comments kids often respect other kids who seem like they don't give a shit and can come up with witty responses to teasing of course that's easier said than done and you can't really fake confidence when you don't feel confident at all in this situation it's really tough

most likely your niece has been abused online by a peadophile with this fetish it’s very common when children have been exposed in one way to sexual contact material that they then seek out that same type of contact conversation this is absolutely not her fault she’s been exposed somehow to this world and it’s very hard to reverse that interest now without some professional intervention if you haven’t already try and establish if any of these people appear to be adults then call the police most likely they are adult sexual predators or at least some amongst them they need reporting because they will likely be doing this with other children police will now even work with police in other countries to catch these people your niece is very much a victim and should not be shamed or punished but you do need to set clear boundaries and expectations of her and remove all devices school need to be aware and on board too i’m not an expert in monitoring devices but believe when the time comes to give her phone etc back that you can ‘clone’ her phone in a sense so you can see in real time what she’s doing ask your school for support around this as they should know a service to refer you to to help with this i’m a manager in children’s safeguarding services and unfortunately this is far far too common i’m really sorry it’s happened to your niece and you

first you’re doing a lot learning a lot handling a lot and experiencing a lot all at once take a second to breathe now understand your niece is going through a lot too we don’t know the circumstances from which she was removed from her home and in your care but this behavior is not typical and she is in need of some serious therapy and quick i would call the pediatrician and the insurance and start calling the pediatrician can help get things moving with a referral and sometimes get a child into a therapist office fast when needed second no phone or internet privileges this is to keep her safe i understand you need to get a hold of her and you have options there are parental safety phones and apps and flip phones if she has an iphone there’s a parental option that she needs permission to download anything i would seriously consider a phone with no internet access as far as her school computer there should be precautions in place to prevent kids from accessing social media—i would tell the school of this incident third she’s and she does not need social media including pinterest look up what social media does and decide for yourself the correlation between mental illnesses in teens and social media is real there are law suits right now about this but do your own research and come to a conclusion fourth clearly she doesn’t understand internet danger i’d contact your case worker and see if they have advice on moving forward and also to document this this also sounds like it warrants a police report these strangers are in possession of her explicit photos minor and have been communicating explicitly with a minor lastly get yourself some help with going through this this is going to a long road of helping your niece take care and good luck one day at a time

and use mobile internet during trips before i could answer the phone call dropped i called him back but the line was busy i knew something was up so i ran home it took me about seconds after his call asked him what happened and he said he thought i was missing he said he needs to tell me something i said sure he said i thought it was an emergency and called sure enough his phone started ringing and it was a local police department calling back to make sure we are fine the lady said she received a phone call from a child stating that his father was missing i assured her that everything is fine indeed and i was only gone for minutes taking a garbage out prior to hurricane hitting the area she said thank you for confirming and that was the end of it but my son was in so much stress he thought the police will come and take him away from us and place him with foster parents his best friend's parents are going through a really bad divorce that's where he gets his info from i did my best to convince him it is not going to happen unless he will continue calling the police every time i'm gone for less than minutes obviously i'm not going to leave him home alone again even if he begs me to we had a long conversation about what real emergencies are and when it's a good call to get the police involved he was shaken for about minutes or so after it happened and then went to his usual self he brought it up again when my wife came home and we went through what the emergency situations are again he truly believed it was an emergency and i was lost or something that is why he from him downvotes will not make me do it as well

i have a vivid memory from my childhood… my parents my younger sister and me were moving my grandmother into a condo closer to our home back then we had a little portable tv with a dvd player my parents plugged it into the wall and put a movie on for us while they moved stuff in well i had never moved before i was probably around the same age as your son actually and didn’t realize how long this took especially with them needing to catch an elevator for every trip in my child mind i thought “oh my god my parents have gone missing” and my sister and i looked out the window to find them — nowhere to be seen freaked out we paused our movie and hopped in the elevator to go down to the lobby to search for our parents my parents didn’t see us in the condo and we all essentially went up and down the elevators missing each other each time and i genuinely thought my parents either disappeared or left us for good boy were they mad when they finally found us this was slightly before cell phones at least i didn’t have one yet so there was no way to text call ping and the lobby people thought we were playing around so they said nothing

first of all child knowing how to call and having access to a phone is an awesome thing and does save people's lives your child did his best for you with the information he thought he had before cellphones kids of all ages had access to phones in every home and also called him having a phone is not the issue second my own freaking phone called when i was on a walk my lock screen was on my phone was on silent because it almost always is my phone called from the emergency screen and all they heard was rustling and heavy breathing they called and called me back several times we live in the country and i don't know how fast gps works but they were starting the process to try to find where the call came from when i took out my phone to look at the time i realized my phone was ringing and i answered the operator was so happy it was a butt dial and not someone being attacked mistakes happen i felt awful time is a very hard concept especially during a frightening experience real or perceived i am sure this was a learning experience for all of you please don't shame your son for trying to help you he did his best just work on new strategies to keep track of time and make several attempts to contact mom and dad first

it sounds like an anxiety flare bless him he suddenly worried a lot you were gone my year old can be similar during pandemic i was at home basically for two years and we were never apart the first time i had to leave minor dental surgery he was massively anxious about how long i’d be gone as he’d gotten used to me being there took a while for the anxiety about me not being around to lessen as life started going back to normal i have a hypnotherapy audio kids anxiety pack that you are welcome to try for free i have an year old and i play them at night sometimes includes anxiety elimination confidence and positivity etc they aren’t much different from the adult ones i listen to essentially tells you to close eyes relax think of a happy safe space if you could help him think of one before hand might help and then affirmations about letting go of anxiety

have you noticed any tendency towards anxiety in general absolutely no judgement if so some kids just come wired that way mine did the reason i ask is that some intuitive kind things that any parent might do to soothe and reassure such a child can actually accidentally make things worse this book is worth reading on the topic *anxiety relief for kids on the spot strategies to help your child overcome worry panic and avoidance* by bridget flynn walker phd of course i don't know your kid so this may not apply at all but with my anxiety prone kid i seriously wish i'd learned earlier how to help effectively

there's a lot of good comments here that highlight the importance of boundaries and educating your daughter a yr old is old enough to start learning financial responsibility i personally would recommend a prepaid debt card that she can use for these subscriptions using her own money that she's been able to save up or that she works for these can be reloaded when they run out which also gives you the ability to limit her on how much she can spend if there's no money on the card her subscriptions will automatically cancel and you xan take the opportunity to teach her how to cancel the subscription she pays for if a prepaid card feels like too much you can also manage subscriptions with gift cards that can only be used on specific apps she needs to be able to see how her money is being spent teaching her how to use a budget can also help her but this will only work if you follow through with establishing boundaries with grandma i'd also give her an electronics time out she abused phone privileges so she looses the phone for a set amount of time when you give it back make sure she understands why she lost the phone and what the consequence was and that it will be taken away for longer if it happens again if she values having a phone she will respect the boundaries i might recommend that if a phone is important for communication then if the problem persists after taking it away more than once then you xan downgrade her to a flip phone that only has minutes these were things my parents did in similar situations when i was her age and it made a huge difference you got this mama

let me start off by saying roblox is full of kids but not only you need to talk to your daughter about a few things first off never give anyone too much information and **never** let anyone else know your password make sure you write passwords down accounts can have a lot of in game ”items” that your daughter probably worked hard for also warn her about scamming a lot of people trick others online to steal their items items can have value in real life don’t know if that’s the case in roblox i had an item stolen from me that i had worked hard for but in another game make sure to not take words personal and serious this happened to me but on social media i was about and someone called me a dickhead i cried and told my mom i learned from there that it’s normal and this tip is for you i am into gaming and got into it young here are a few tips take breaks this is very important and is very good to create a habit out of tell your daughter to get up while she’s playing and do some physical movements could be stretching or anything really while taking the breaks make sure to drink water staying hydrated as you know is very important and can be forgotten as time can be lost track of when playing don’t let your daughter have social medias maybe when she becomes old enough to actually have an account on most social medias i wouldn’t recommend getting social medias at all as they just affect you in negative ways and are addicting i can’t think of more right now my phone is almost dead i will go to sleep and respond to any of your questions tomorrow i might just be but i would call myself mature enough and experienced enough to know what i am talking about

i went through a similar situation with my year old boy and was absolutely floored by his behavior towards another kid in a group online bullying situation while he had other consequences apologizing had him read a kid friendly article on what bullying does to others… it’s tough to take away their phone completely one because we need to be able to get ahold of him because we’re both working parents and he’s active in sports and academics and two of how his school uses qr codes to provide access to almost everything each classes syllabus links to parent forms registration for clubs sports registration etc which is a whole other issue in itself anyway i blocked or deleted everything on his phone for two months like internet access can’t download any apps airdrop the whole nine yards basically i turned his phone into a “dumb phone” because he only had access to his camera for qr codes texting and calling i limited his contacts during certain hours through screen time on his apple phone and he couldn’t add contacts unless i approved them anyway looking back i’m glad i took it so seriously because then he had to take it his behavior seriously as well if that makes sense hope this helps

there are a couple different really important issues here number one is the chatting with strangers your daughter now knows exactly how easy it is to pretend to be someone she’s not but i doubt she has considered how easily she could be fooled by someone pretending to be a child as well in fact that could be what’s happening right now so out of a ton of concern i would approach this situation very carefully but firmly as soon as possible i have personally let my kids know this is the biggest concern and they are never to give out their names town school name etc and that if anyone is ever threatening them even with real information they weren’t supposed to give out that they can come to us no matter what we’ve explicitly explained the types of threats predators and scammers might use so that hopefully they can recognize that and still come to us i’ve described in detail how they can threaten to hurt your family how they can offer to take you away for awhile of your parents are hounding you etc all the things in my opinion knowledge is power here and i often do it in the car where they have to listen and can’t go away does she know about bark and we’re there any rules put in place where she knew you could look at her devices at any time i would be honest and concerned but try to avoid showing anger i think i would avoid any punishments at this time although moving screen time to a common room might be a suggestion

i dont believe any of my kids have adhd so i dont know how helpful my experience is but i've dealt with soooooo many meltdowns over getting off of games after many many many of them and reminding them that they get further from games the more they don't accept the answer the warnings are more effective and the transition is easier it's happened before i told my year old now okay that's one day and if you keep on you're gonna get a second day he got up to days one time and i had to hold him to it it wasn't easy because he talked to me about it several times every of those days i just reminded him why he lost them hes not allowed to act like that now when he hears a warning he believes me and may protest but doesn't take it to an extent maybe consistency in understanding that they're not going to get to play if they can't follow along with the warning of when it's time to get off 🤷 i really don't know what i'm doing but it's what worked for me i'm sorry you're having a rough go

i have a year old who plays educational games on my phone full blown hossy fit meltdows happen when she's told time is up i set an alarm when the alarm goes off she has to give back the phone i warn her when we are getting close to time up if she's close to finishing a puzzle i let her finish and then she must hand it over if she refuses she is warned that she will loose game privileges the next day if she still doesn't give it back shes told again that she won't be playing her game tomorrow and to give me back my phone or it will be another day as well and then i stick to it it does make some difference but it's not total lain sailing
when she can't disconnect from the game she takes a break for a few days it's important to keep giving her chances to improve make sure you are staying calm while she is upset

it sounds like she's in control here and i'm not saying that to be mean judgemental or anything i'm definitely a pushover parent myself you say that she throws a fit until you give her more time you started at hour only but are now at she's going to continue to push the limit because she knows you'll give in before taking it away which i honestly don't really agree with maybe try strictly enforcing the rules sit down and explain the rules you get hour no more you can have a minute warning minute warning and minute warning and then i will be taking the game for the night end of story let her throw her tantrum have fun wearing yourself out i've learned that for my son yo with audhd things are best when it's in day increments or at most days so everything starts over again in the morning otherwise it becomes a sort of why even try i'm never going to do better ever i also try not to give more punishments for meltdowns that don't include violence for example i take the switch away and he stomps his foot whines and cries runs to his room and pouts for an hour oh well you just wasted an hour i don't negotiate or give him attention he can try again tomorrow i will say as someone who loves minecraft myself even i struggle with putting the controller down sometimes i just need to finish this building i just need more nights and i can get the diamonds i need but only more trees need to be chopped down maybe some suggestions to help would be playing with her sometimes and letting her see you struggling to put the game down oh man i really want to keep playing but i know that if i don't start dinner now it won't be ready in time and my stomach is growling i'm sad i can't play but i'm looking forward to food hey what if we cooked together and upping the positive rewards attention when she's put it away

i have a child who has had issues with this and we use parental controls to remove the power struggle over it and it has helped many devices such as switches and tablets have timers that lock the device after a certain amount of time they give time up reminders too so the child isn't totally surprised by it i would avoid any devices that do not have parental controls then utilize the parental controls on the ones that do sit them down and let them know ahead of time that the device is timed for hour each day and then it won't work any more then follow through on using it and don't add more time for that day when they do have a tantrum you can focus on empathy instead of having to bargain with them to do something that may truly be too difficult for them

it takes time for them to learn to control it my daughter used to be this way now i tell her the time that she needs to be off by and she will close the tablet and put it away herself she knows if she chooses to have a meltdown or not comply she loses the privilege she's and we have been practicing for years now took her a while when she gets the tablet there is always a moment of connection where i remind her you have x amount of time if you choose to get upset you won't have any time tomorrow

set a schedule and stick to it she’ll get used to it when i enabled screen time with limitations there were freak outs at first but they got used to it screens go off at pm we shower read and get ready for bed and year old

let’s recalibrate the way you see moms some moms bake my sister is a crunchy mom she makes the cute bento lunches for her kindergartener homemade granola bars for her toddler every dinner is from scratch she sews their clothes and does all sorts of neat things like that she’s a great mom some moms read and work my sister in law is amazingly smart and scholarly she teaches university and does research her kindergartener speaks + languages and goes to conferences with her she’s a great mom some moms craft and run and game and work full time my kindergartener does road races with us and helps pick out colors of yarn we play age appropriate games together pokémon skylanders and they learn how to be strategic and a good winner loser i’m a good mom moms come in all shapes and sizes we don’t fit the cookie cutter mold of the s ideal mom and that’s okay your kid won’t like everything you like and that’s okay they won’t be traumatized because you have your own interests if anything knowing parents have their own interests and are their own person can help children establish their own personalities interests and opinions with less pressure and struggle as long as there is respect love and care you’re exactly the mom your kid needs

i game with my year old all the time i also make sure that i am setting healthy boundaries by only playing for an hour or so after chores homework and also making sure we take breaks to play outside and socialize with others nothing wrong with the games just model health behavior with them
i think you’ll probably be more disappointed that she may get into baking arts and craft and the like it seems like whatever our mothers do is uncool and kids do the exact opposite

i can’t speak from a future stand point but i currently have a yo and another on the way partner and i are both gamers as well pc ps switch i try to do most of my gaming when he’s sleeping as well but the odd time we will play something when he’s awake on that note we do so many other things with him l between playing crafts getting outdoors and even have him assisting in the kitchen cooking baking etc we also include him in our daily ongoings of tidying i think the key is balance i agree with u aseapersonbynight about recalibrating how you view moms it takes all kinds of moms to make the world go round from the outside looking in there always seems to be someone doing it “better” which in reality is not better it’s just different i have friends with kids they seem to be able to work full time find all this time to make everything from scratch do laundry all while keeping their house spotless while i have in the past felt i was an “inferior” mom when in reality i’m doing all very similar things i reminded myself that my child is health fed and loved and that’s all i can ask for could my house be cleaner if i did game maybe but maybe i wouldn’t do it anyways give yourself some grace we don’t have to give up our hobbies and sense of self when we become moms we adapt so we can still do something for ourselves you’re doing a great job

i game and watch tv and crochet and play with my kid and bake cakes and do laundry and cook dinner i play or watch tv while she's awake it teaches her to learn to play by herself when i first started being a stay at home mom i felt the same way as you i thought i was only allowed to clean and cook and i started getting so stressed out because that meant i never had time to do anything that i wanted to do my husband has had to instill into my brain that the house doesn't have to be spotless every day and i don't have to cook every day to be a good mother he and i were raised very differently so i'm glad that he believes that and it's taken some work to get to where we are but he also helps me around the house when he gets off work like with cooking or cleaning out feeding the toddler or bathing her there is no perfect mom only the perfect mom for your kids you can teach them your values that you want them to learn while still gaming some days i still neoprene i'm supposed to just clean and cook and be miserable but other days i don't have such a guilty conscience

never stop being who you are just because society tells you to be a certain way if anything you should be proud of who you are and for being able to be your most authentic self you should never be ashamed of your interests as long as it is not harming anyone

i play pc games and sometimes console i am not giving up gaming anytime soon i have made a significant effort to learn to do certain things i wished my parents taught me things i felt would have made my life a lot easier i didn't have anyone teach me how to cook or how to manage my finances two things which i felt would have significantly affected some of my life choices either having a better diet being a better cook and how to avoid unnecessary debt i think that if you don't want your kid to be addicted to gaming then you yourself should be aware of how much time you spend on gaming too try to do other things in addition to gaming so that isn't your child's and your family's only hobby for instance my husband and i game on a daily basis however we still make home cooked meals go for walks go to the gym go to the park enroll our son in sports do crafts color and have days filled without just being glued to a computer i do specific things to create an environment that will help my son be well rounded also you may want to open up your perspective of what a typical mom is supposed to be you don't want your bias to carry over to your children

hey my kids have grown up around video games my babies fell asleep being held while we played games all of our kids are excellent students and they grew up playing video games too they started on abc mouse as soon as they took an actual interest in games like months old all started prek being able to read and write which their teachers were super surprised about their whole lives we have made sure to show that while gaming is great real life always comes first we make family priority and no one is allowed to play games or watch tv without knocking out chores homework and hour of “reading time” first daddy goes to work when he comes home he spends time with the kids helps with homework helps with dinner and whatever needs doing before he plays games and that helps i think by setting the biggest example for them i’m a sahm so i tend to use my kid free time while they are at school to play games so when they come home they see me shutting my games off and spending time with them i usually do chores after they get on the bus til about lunchtime and then game a few hours before they get home cooking dinner and doing whatever else needs doing honestly there’s nothing wrong with being a gaming family so long as you make a point to teach the kiddos priorities like homework education household chores and going to work is important

moms do all kinds of things i loathe cooking and make sculpture and do carpentry we also have a gamer household spouse works in the game industry i wanted to address your concerns about game addiction which i think are valid especially for kids gaming doesn't seem to be harmful in itself but it does eat up time that would otherwise be spent doing activities that have very strong positives for development reading playing outside studying building being bored one theory seeking to explain why girls now outperform boys at almost every academic level all the way up to graduate school is that boys spend considerably more time gaming than girls; girls are still reading books folks like my spouse spend hours every day pouring over data to make their game more fun and compelling to players spouse and his team members are good at their jobs so even if they don't set out to make an addictive product what will be the result of a few years of this effort the game is really really really compelling an immature brain has frankly no chance of resisting its allure i did not want to be constantly fighting about time limits so our rule therefore was no screen amusement for kiddo during the week weekends only it worked really well we relaxed it for covid so kid could hang out with friends online but by then kiddo was in high school

im a dad year old and month old boys not a mum but am a gamer and i sort of wrestled with this too i came to video games later in life and my childhood was very outdoorsy and i'd really like the same for my kids having said that video games have been a bit of a saviour for me as i'm sure you know parenting babies can be a crippling emotional mess at times the thing i dont see people talking about a lot is that its almost impossible to think about other things while you're playing videogames turning your brain off or focusing on something that's not parenting is such a gift some days i think a trap a lot of parents fall into myself included is suddenly viewing their lives through what is good for their kids but you were a person in the world before you kid came along and you need to do things for you as long as youre not endangering your child its ok for you to have a thing just for you and with your partner i wish my wife played videogames it would be a way to do something together that we both enjoy at home and spend fun time together something that's pretty hard in covid toddler times parenting is a lot of guilt in my experience but try not to feel bad about doing things that are just for you; being a more fulfilled person will translate into being a better parent

you're amazing this is a great comment i had to claim my free award just to give it to you it's crazy that this seems to be somewhat of a new concept and that traditional parenting roles seem to be changing much more quickly in our generation than perhaps they have in years i think you're right that great moms can come in all shapes and sizes and don't have to fit a cookie cutter parenting model ops post clearly reflects that some have trouble with this concept because it deviates from what parenting was in previous generations my hope is that this new way of parenting has a positive impact on our children and allows them to be who they want to be as well and makes being able to freely be different from the average person the norm rather than the exception i can't imagine how much differently i would have turned out if it wasn't pounded into my head that moms do this and dads do this i like to think i do a good job being an active father but sometimes i fall into more traditional roles as a husband which is a sin because my wife works just as much and just as hard as i do we all need to do a lot of recalibrating on the way we think looking through the lens of thank you for your insightful comment i'm a year old late night gamer dad with young children whose partner despises gaming but i think it's important to feel confident that we can all parent how we feel comfortable and forget trying to conform to anyone else's expectations or old cultural norms
